taxonomy.name: Onboarding & Identity
taxonomy.summary: Account creation, trust structures, and authority governance for Edge.

taxonomy.name: Asset & Cash Movements
taxonomy.summary: Internal, external, and in-specie transfers plus trading workspace upgrades.

taxonomy.name: Pension & Super Services
taxonomy.summary: Pension payment management, COR validation, contribution caps, and SG updates.

taxonomy.name: Reporting & Analytics
taxonomy.summary: Interactive reporting, custom date ranges, and family group analytics.

taxonomy.name: Protection & Compliance Support
taxonomy.summary: Insurance transfers, advice fee consent, AML, and regulatory obligations.

taxonomy.name: Experience & Escalation
taxonomy.summary: Communication scripts, escalation matrix, and service recovery essentials.

whatChanged.title: Direct IDPS in-specie transfers (June 2025)
whatChanged.summary: Holdings can move from IDPS to personal accounts without sell-down, preserving cost base and history.
whatChanged.impact: Reduces tax events and accelerates transfers to 5-10 business days.

whatChanged.title: Trading workspace visibility (July 2025)
whatChanged.summary: Trading screens now surface account IDs, account types, unrealised gains, and tax lot data.
whatChanged.impact: Cuts mis-trades and provides compliance-ready detail in one view.

whatChanged.title: Interactive reporting and custom date ranges
whatChanged.summary: Reports accept any date span and provide look-through plus managed account dashboards.
whatChanged.impact: Advisers can answer bespoke performance queries without offline spreadsheets.

whatChanged.title: Password expiry extended to 12 months
whatChanged.summary: Passwords now expire annually with 7-day grace and a calmer login flow.
whatChanged.impact: Reduces reset volume while maintaining MFA readiness.

whatChanged.title: Pension payment schedule control
whatChanged.summary: Payment dates, amounts, and frequencies can be adjusted pre-funding with real-time COR checks.
whatChanged.impact: Agents can resolve pension timing queries immediately while staying ATO compliant.

whatChanged.title: Group-to-retail insurance transfer shortcut
whatChanged.summary: Eligible members can port group Life/TPD/IP cover to CFS Edge retail policies via short-form underwriting.
whatChanged.impact: Prevents cover gaps when clients move super funds.

whatChanged.title: Multi-document advice fee consent
whatChanged.summary: Consent requests now bundle multiple documents with audit trail.
whatChanged.impact: Eliminates fragmented uploads and compliance gaps.

whatChanged.title: Super Guarantee uplift to 12%
whatChanged.summary: Minimum employer SG contributions rise to 12% from 1 July 2025.
whatChanged.impact: Payroll teams must update contributions and communicate with clients.

procedures.title: Adjust pension payment schedule before commencement
procedures.purpose: Update payment frequency, amount, or date while ensuring COR and minimum pension rules are met.
prereqs: Caller authenticated and listed adviser or trustee
Pension account open in Edge with access to Payment Schedule
Confirm authority level allows schedule changes
assumptions: Assumed: Handling time ~6 minutes based on AHT guidance (page 41).

steps.title: Review current schedule
steps.action: Open the pension account → Payment Schedule to view frequency, amount, and next payment.
steps.agentSpeak: Let me bring up your pension payment schedule so we can review the current amount and date together.
validations: Ensure account status is Active before editing.

steps.title: Check COR status
steps.action: Confirm Condition of Release shows Met; if Pending or Under Review, stop schedule edits.
steps.agentSpeak: I can see your release status is {status}. Once it shows Met we can finalise the payment details.
validations: If status Pending or Under Review, trigger COR branch.

steps.title: Modify payment details
steps.action: Select Modify Payment Details to update frequency, amount, and payment date per adviser request.
steps.agentSpeak: I'll adjust the payment to {new details}. The system will check we're still meeting the ATO minimum.
validations: System validates minimum percentage automatically.

steps.title: Verify minimum compliance
steps.action: Review Total Pension Withdrawn vs Minimum Required indicators; resolve any Under target warning.
steps.agentSpeak: Right now the system shows you've drawn ${paid} and need ${minimum}. I'll make sure the new amount keeps you on track.
validations: If status Under target, branch to under-target flow.

steps.title: Confirm effective date
steps.action: Submit change and confirm first payment date with caller; note immediate effect once approved.
steps.agentSpeak: Those updates are live now. The first payment on the new schedule will run on {date}.
validations: Ensure acknowledgement email scheduled.

steps.title: Log call and set follow-up
steps.action: Record summary note including COR status, payment change, and YTD position; set reminder if verification pending.
steps.agentSpeak: I'll send a confirmation outlining the updated payment and where to check your year-to-date total.
validations: Attach supporting documents if adviser provided written instruction.

branches.label: COR status pending
branches.condition: Displayed status is Pending or Under Review

steps.title: Explain requirement
steps.action: Inform caller that COR evidence must be received before payments can be released.
steps.agentSpeak: The ATO needs confirmation of your condition of release. Once we receive the employer separation letter we can start payments.

steps.title: Request documentation
steps.action: Provide acceptable documents and submission channels; lodge task for verification team (2-3 business days).
steps.agentSpeak: Please upload the employer letter via the secure portal or email it to us; verification takes around 2-3 business days.

steps.title: Schedule follow-up
steps.action: Set reminder to check COR status and update client when Met.
steps.agentSpeak: I'll follow up once the status flips to Met so we can lock in your payment timing.

steps.title: Calculate adjustment
steps.action: Determine shortfall using system indicator and propose schedule change.
steps.agentSpeak: You're short by ${shortfall} for this financial year. If we lift the next quarter's payment to ${adjusted}, you'll meet the minimum.

steps.title: Confirm adviser agreement
steps.action: Obtain approval for adjusted amount/frequency before saving changes.
steps.agentSpeak: Does that revised figure work for your client? I can lock it in now.

policy_refs.quote: ATO minimum payment rules by age bands (4% at ages 60-74, scaling to 10% at 85+).
policy_refs.paraphrase: Use the built-in ATO minimum check to keep payments compliant.

policy_refs.quote: System automatically checks condition of release before pension payments.
policy_refs.paraphrase: Do not process payments until COR shows Met.

policy_refs.quote: Total pension withdrawn current FY with status On track / Under target / Over target.
policy_refs.paraphrase: Use YTD dashboard to validate minimum withdrawals.

common_pitfalls: Attempting to update schedule before COR documentation is verified.
Ignoring an Under target warning and leaving client short of minimum.
Failing to send written confirmation outlining the new payment timeline.

procedures.title: Coordinate IDPS in-specie transfer to Edge
procedures.purpose: Move holdings from an IDPS super platform to Edge without triggering a sell-down.
prereqs: Destination account structure set up in Edge
Authority level permits external transfer coordination
assumptions: Assumed: Handling time ~8 minutes given multi-step coordination (page 41 context).

steps.title: Validate eligibility
steps.action: Confirm transfer fits Category C and holdings are transferable (no prohibited assets).
steps.agentSpeak: I'll confirm these holdings qualify for the direct in-specie pathway so we can avoid a sell-down.
validations: Check for restricted assets; branch if required.

steps.title: Initiate transfer in Edge
steps.action: Navigate to source account → Initiate In-Specie Transfer to review holdings and select securities.
steps.agentSpeak: I can see the securities, including codes, cost base, and accrued gains—we'll include the full list unless you specify otherwise.
validations: Ensure destination account matches adviser request.

steps.title: Generate transfer request
steps.action: Produce Transfer Request document with source custodian details and send per platform protocol.
steps.agentSpeak: I'll submit the transfer form to {source custodian}; they usually confirm within a few business days.
validations: Log contact with source platform.

steps.title: Set settlement expectations
steps.action: Advise settlement timeframe (5-10 business days) and note no tax event or history break.
steps.agentSpeak: Settlement typically finalises within 5-10 business days and your cost base stays intact.
validations: Schedule reminder to check status.

steps.title: Monitor performance history reconstruction
steps.action: Track reconstruction SLA and communicate progress using prepared script.
steps.agentSpeak: We'll rebuild historical performance; simpler portfolios finish within about a week, complex ones can take up to four.
validations: Escalate to data team if SLA exceeded.

steps.title: Confirm completion and document
steps.action: Send confirmation once holdings credit and note follow-up email for full performance history availability.
steps.agentSpeak: I'll email once everything lands and your reports show the full history back to inception.
validations: Attach statement to CRM record.

branches.label: Holding not eligible
branches.condition: Holding is unlisted, international with restrictions, or under margin lending

steps.title: Explain limitation
steps.action: Advise adviser that specific holding must follow manual or direct transfer path and outline additional consent required.
steps.agentSpeak: This managed fund requires the issuer's consent, so we'll coordinate a manual transfer which can take an extra few days.

steps.title: Escalate to specialist
steps.action: Create ticket for manual processing or margin release as appropriate.
steps.agentSpeak: I'll lodge this with our specialist team and keep you updated on their turnaround.

branches.label: Performance history delay
branches.condition: Reconstruction exceeds SLA or data incomplete

steps.title: Clarify data gap
steps.action: Identify missing period and reference reconstruction status.
steps.agentSpeak: We have complete history to {date}; the earlier period is still being rebuilt because the source only provided partial records.

steps.title: Provide interim guidance
steps.action: Offer interim reporting and promised completion date using prepared language.
steps.agentSpeak: Use the statement from transfer date onward for now; full backdating will appear by {target date}.

steps.title: Escalate if urgent
steps.action: Escalate to data migration if adviser requires acceleration for compliance or tax purposes.
steps.agentSpeak: I'll prioritise this with our data team and confirm once they close the gap.

policy_refs.quote: June 2025 process allows direct electronic in-specie transfers with no sell-down.
policy_refs.paraphrase: Use direct pathway to avoid crystallising gains.

policy_refs.quote: Reconstruction SLA ranges from 3-5 business days to 2-4 weeks depending on complexity.
policy_refs.paraphrase: Set expectations using published SLA bands.

common_pitfalls: Forgetting to flag restricted holdings early, delaying settlement.
Not logging source platform submission details in CRM.

procedures.title: Deliver family-group look-through performance report
procedures.purpose: Generate consolidated, filterable reporting with underlying holdings exposure for a family group.
prereqs: Family group structure configured in Edge
assumptions: Assumed: Preparation and delivery approx 7 minutes including follow-up email.

steps.title: Clarify reporting scope
steps.action: Select Family Group report level when multiple related accounts are requested.
steps.agentSpeak: I'll run the family view so you can see total wealth across all connected accounts.
validations: Check privacy controls so each member sees appropriate data.

steps.title: Set custom date range
steps.action: Apply adviser-specified dates using custom range controls.
steps.agentSpeak: I'll align the report from {start} to {end} so it matches your accountant's period.
validations: Ensure date range includes relevant transactions.

steps.title: Enable look-through analytics
steps.action: Toggle look-through to show underlying fund holdings, geographic, sector, and currency exposure.
steps.agentSpeak: With look-through on, you'll see the actual holdings inside each fund, including sector and currency splits.
validations: Verify data completeness; note any holdings without look-through.

steps.title: Highlight exposures with filters
steps.action: Use interactive filters to surface requested insights.
steps.agentSpeak: Filtering to US equities shows 30% exposure—helpful for your diversification discussion.
validations: Capture notes or screenshots for documentation.

steps.title: Export and schedule delivery
steps.action: Export PDF/Excel and set up monthly or quarterly email subscription if requested.
steps.agentSpeak: I've exported the PDF for today and scheduled the same report to email you each month.
validations: Confirm recipient permissions.

steps.title: Document insights and follow-up
steps.action: Summarise exposures, note adviser requests, and add follow-up tasks if further analysis needed.
steps.agentSpeak: I've added notes on the concentrated positions so we can revisit after your review.
validations: Attach exported report if policy permits.

branches.label: Family privacy constraint
branches.condition: Family member should not see consolidated view

steps.title: Adjust visibility
steps.action: Ensure only adviser and trustees access family report; provide single-account versions to others.
steps.agentSpeak: For privacy, I'll keep the consolidated report adviser-only and send individual account reports to each member.

branches.label: Incomplete look-through data
branches.condition: Underlying holdings missing for some funds

steps.title: Explain limitation
steps.action: Identify which funds lack look-through and outline why.
steps.agentSpeak: Fund X doesn't provide daily component data, so we're showing aggregate values only.

steps.title: Offer workaround
steps.action: Suggest exporting available data and flagging missing components for follow-up with manager.
steps.agentSpeak: I'll escalate to get the underlying file from the manager and update you once it feeds through.

policy_refs.quote: Three report generation levels including family group consolidated views.
policy_refs.paraphrase: Use the correct report scope for adviser discussions.

policy_refs.quote: Reports support any custom date range such as FY or life events.
Look-through data reveals asset class, geography, sector, and currency exposure.
policy_refs.paraphrase: Enable look-through to address diversification questions.

common_pitfalls: Sending consolidated report to individuals without checking privacy settings.
Forgetting to align date ranges with accountant or adviser parameters.
Not documenting filters used, making follow-up conversations harder.

procedures.title: Support adviser with password expiry and MFA onboarding
procedures.purpose: Reset credentials under the extended 12-month policy and prepare advisers for the MFA rollout.
prereqs: Access to security profile showing last reset date
Awareness of upcoming MFA phase for caller type
assumptions: Assumed: 5-minute handling aligned to credential reset flows.

steps.title: Confirm identity and reset eligibility
steps.action: Verify caller and check password expiry date plus grace window.
steps.agentSpeak: Thanks for verifying those details. I can see your password is due to expire on {date} with a seven-day grace period.
validations: If security incident flag present, branch to incident flow.

steps.title: Explain new expiry policy
steps.action: Reinforce 12-month cycle and notification cadence.
steps.agentSpeak: We moved from quarterly resets to annual resets on 1 June 2025, so you only need to update once a year unless there's unusual activity.
validations: Ensure caller aware of 14-day reminder email.

steps.title: Send reset link and set expectations
steps.action: Trigger reset email/SMS and outline the simplified login flow without countdown.
steps.agentSpeak: I've sent the reset link—once you update, the login screen will simply ask for the passcode without that timer we removed in July.
validations: Advise on 15-minute passcode validity and re-request option.

steps.title: Prep for MFA rollout
steps.action: Brief adviser on MFA phase relevant to platform (FirstNet mandatory Jan-Feb 2026; others optional initially).
steps.agentSpeak: Starting early 2026 you'll need an authenticator app for FirstNet—Google Authenticator or Microsoft Authenticator both work.
validations: Flag if caller needs backup codes guidance.

steps.title: Document and close
steps.action: Record reset action, MFA briefing, and any follow-up tasks in CRM.
steps.agentSpeak: I'll note that we covered the MFA timeline today. Reach out if you need help installing the app.
validations: Provide ticket number if escalated.

branches.label: Security incident reset
branches.condition: Account flagged for security incident or unauthorised access

steps.title: Explain forced reset
steps.action: Advise caller that immediate reset is required due to security alert.
steps.agentSpeak: Our system detected unusual activity, so we're forcing a reset right away to keep the account secure.

steps.title: Coordinate compliance follow-up
steps.action: Notify compliance per breach protocol and provide caller with expected callback timeframe.
steps.agentSpeak: Our compliance team will review and reach out within 24 hours with any further steps.

branches.label: Needs MFA installation help
branches.condition: Caller unfamiliar with authenticator setup or locked out

steps.title: Provide setup guidance
steps.action: Walk through downloading approved app and scanning QR code; mention remember device option for Edge.
steps.agentSpeak: Install the authenticator app, scan the code in Security Settings, and you can tick 'remember this device for 30 days' on trusted computers.

steps.title: Issue backup codes if required
steps.action: Generate backup codes for temporary access and note distribution.
steps.agentSpeak: If you ever lose the device, these backup codes will let you in—store them securely.

policy_refs.quote: Password expiry extended from 90 days to 12 months with 14-day notification and 7-day grace.
policy_refs.paraphrase: Reference new expiry cadence during resets.

policy_refs.quote: FirstNet MFA mandatory Jan-Feb 2026; other platforms optional initially.
policy_refs.paraphrase: Advise callers on phase relevant to their platform access.

common_pitfalls: Not checking for security incident flags before processing reset.
Failing to brief advisers on upcoming MFA deadlines.
Skipping documentation of reset and MFA education in CRM.

modules.title: Edge Platform Architecture Foundations
objectives: Explain why CFS Edge replaced the FirstWrap and FirstChoice stacks.
Compare overnight batch processing with Edge real-time streaming and reporting.
Outline the 2022-2024 separation milestones that cleared 247 technical debt items.
modules.explanation: Contrast the legacy FirstWrap and FirstChoice constraints with Edge streaming services, capacity uplift, and the separation timeline.
procedureSteps: Position the FNZ partnership and redesign in adviser friendly language.
Summarise legacy pain points callers recall and how Edge removes them.
Set expectations on migration checkpoints, data validation, and callback cadence.
edgeCases: Adviser insists Edge still runs overnight batches - walk through the live streaming proof points.
Large dealer doubts concurrency limits - share the 50,000 session design target.
Caller mentions old three day performance rebuilds - quote the automated SLA.

miniCheck.prompt: Which legacy constraint drove the Edge rebuild with FNZ?

options.label: Monolithic databases that forced 4-6 hour data refresh cycles
options.feedback: Correct - the overnight batch model was a major adviser pain point (page 1).

options.label: Low adviser brand awareness outside Australia
options.feedback: Brand perception is important but not the architectural driver.

options.label: Contact centre headcount caps during peak season
options.feedback: Staffing pressures are noted elsewhere but not as the rebuild trigger.

options.label: Regulators banning integrations to adviser CRMs
options.feedback: Edge actually expands API connectivity, it was not banned.

miniCheck.prompt: How can an agent best describe Edge concurrency improvements?

options.label: Explain the move to a cloud distributed architecture scaling beyond 50,000 sessions
options.feedback: Correct - the training guide highlights the new capacity target (page 2).

options.label: State that batch windows now run twice per day
options.feedback: Batch windows were removed, so this would be incorrect.

options.label: Mention the 23 direct API connections that remove duplicate data entry
options.feedback: Correct - the API footprint is a major improvement (page 2).

options.label: Promise a permanent five minute nightly outage window
options.feedback: No nightly outage window is documented in the guide.

miniCheck.prompt: True or false: Edge removes batch refresh and manual reporting bottlenecks advisers remember.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

example.label: Migration reassurance
example.scenario: A dealer principal calls after a legacy outage and wants proof Edge will behave differently.
example.application: Acknowledge the incident history, contrast real time streaming with the 4-6 hour batches, and share the separation milestone summary deck.

takeaways: Edge removes batch refresh and manual reporting bottlenecks advisers remember.
Architecture talking points should link directly to adviser and investor outcomes.
Migration updates must stay anchored to measurable platform improvements.
nextActions: Bookmark the architecture explainer deck within the knowledge base.
Practice summarising the separation milestones using plain language.

modules.title: Onboarding Clients on CFS Edge
objectives: Map the onboarding workflow across individual, trust, and SMSF structures.
Clarify mandatory identity artefacts and when to escalate to compliance or verification teams.
Explain adviser authority tiers and how Edge enforces digital signatures and witnessing rules.
modules.explanation: Guide advisers through digital identity capture, trust documentation, and condition of release governance in the Edge onboarding workspace.
procedureSteps: Confirm entity type, residency, and adviser authority before collecting documents.
Walk through digital ID capture, document uploads, and condition of release gating rules.
Schedule follow ups for ASIC, ABN, or deed validation so momentum is not lost.
edgeCases: Trust deed is missing or outdated - advise on uploading a certified copy before proceeding.
SMSF ABN appears inactive - remind the adviser Edge blocks setup until ASIC shows Registered.
High contribution limits - explain when two signatories are required above the $500k threshold.

miniCheck.prompt: Which condition of release status must display before pension onboarding can proceed?

options.label: Met
options.feedback: Correct - Edge prevents pension activation until condition of release shows Met (page 23).

options.label: Pending adviser signature
options.feedback: Pending indicates further validation is needed.

options.label: Deemed satisfied
options.feedback: This status is not part of the Edge gating rules.

options.label: Waived
options.feedback: Conditions of release cannot be waived in the workflow.

miniCheck.prompt: What is the correct response when an SMSF ABN shows inactive?

options.label: Ask the trustee to refresh ASIC registration before Edge can continue
options.feedback: Correct - the platform enforces live ASIC status as a blocker (page 5).

options.label: Continue onboarding while a manual override is raised
options.feedback: Overrides are not permitted for compliance gates.

options.label: Switch the account to an individual profile temporarily
options.feedback: Switching entity type introduces compliance issues.

options.label: Escalate directly to the payments queue
options.feedback: Payments cannot resolve an ASIC registration issue.

miniCheck.prompt: True or false: Always lock down entity and authority data before diving into forms.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

example.label: Multi-entity onboarding
example.scenario: An adviser wants to open a personal cash account, an investment wrap, and a trustee account in one call.
example.application: Clarify the entity order, remind them to upload trust deeds and condition of release evidence, and schedule a follow up once ASIC validation clears.

takeaways: Always lock down entity and authority data before diving into forms.
Use the digital checklist to track ASIC, ABN, and deed confirmations.
Escalate only when compliance artefacts cannot be supplied through the portal.
nextActions: Rehearse the triage script covering individual, trust, and SMSF differences.
Keep personal notes on typical ASIC turnaround times for quick coaching.

modules.title: Asset Transfers and IDPS In-Specie Strategy
objectives: Describe how Edge handles internal, external, and IDPS in-specie transfers.
Set accurate settlement expectations and explain potential tax outcomes.
Coach advisers on performance history reconstruction and client updates.
modules.explanation: Differentiate internal, external, and IDPS in-specie transfers, quoting accurate settlement windows, tax considerations, and history reconstruction steps.
procedureSteps: Confirm the transfer category and originating platform or custodian.
Explain settlement timeframes, fees, and whether tax events may apply.
Document custodian contacts and schedule follow ups for reconstruction status.
edgeCases: External provider is slow to respond - remind advisers of the 3-8 business day window and note the sending platform.
IDPS custodian rejects a holding - check the eligibility list before resubmitting.
Client expects a tax free outcome - clarify when capital gains may be triggered outside super.

miniCheck.prompt: What settlement window should be quoted for a Category A internal transfer?

options.label: 1-2 business days with no tax implication
options.feedback: Correct - internal transfers move quickly without triggering tax (page 7).

options.label: 5-10 business days with potential capital gains tax
options.feedback: This timing applies to IDPS in-specie transfers, not internal movements.

options.label: Up to four weeks while performance history rebuilds
options.feedback: History reconstruction is separate from the settlement window.

options.label: Next day provided a supervisor approves the request
options.feedback: Supervisor approval is not documented as a requirement.

miniCheck.prompt: Which talking points reassure advisers about IDPS in-specie moves?

options.label: Explain that holdings move without sell downs so cost base records stay intact
options.feedback: Correct - preserving cost base history is a key benefit (page 9).

options.label: Mention that settlement now lands inside 5-10 business days
options.feedback: Correct - the June 2025 uplift delivers the faster window (page 9).

options.label: Promise daily tax reporting while the transfer is open
options.feedback: The guide does not promise daily tax reporting updates.

options.label: State that all corporate actions pause until settlement completes
options.feedback: Corporate actions continue unless a custodian specifies otherwise.

miniCheck.prompt: True or false: Always identify the transfer category before quoting timelines or tax outcomes.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

example.label: IDPS reassurance
example.scenario: An adviser who experienced long delays on the legacy stack asks whether cost base and income records will carry into Edge.
example.application: Outline the in-specie upgrade, confirm cost base preservation, and log a follow up for the custodian settlement confirmation.

takeaways: Always identify the transfer category before quoting timelines or tax outcomes.
In-specie upgrades dramatically reduced adviser friction for IDPS transitions.
Every transfer case note should capture custodian contacts and callback commitments.
nextActions: Review the in-specie eligibility list at least once per week.
Save the settlement timeline cheat sheet to your personal quick links.

modules.title: Transacting and Managing Accounts
objectives: Demonstrate the trading workspace upgrades including tax lots and unrealised gain views.
Clarify cash sweep rules, pending trade visibility, and settlement cut offs.
Outline how to monitor corporate actions and managed account instructions.
modules.explanation: Support trade placement, cash sweeps, and corporate action coordination using the upgraded trading workspace.
procedureSteps: Confirm account type, adviser authority, and available cash before placing trades.
Walk through trade entry, pre-trade compliance prompts, and pending orders.
Schedule reminders for settlement cut offs and corporate action deadlines.
edgeCases: Adviser cannot see pending orders - check the activity timeline filters and refresh cadence.
Client expects manual performance rebuilds - show the live performance widgets and dashboards.
Corporate action instruction is overdue - escalate to the corporate actions queue before the cut off.

miniCheck.prompt: Which workspace enhancement helps advisers validate managed account trades?

options.label: Tax lot visibility alongside unrealised gains
options.feedback: Correct - the trading workspace surfaces tax lots and gains (page 12).

options.label: A forced five minute delay before every order
options.feedback: No mandatory delay is mentioned in the guide.

options.label: Removal of compliance prompts during order entry
options.feedback: Compliance prompts remain to protect investors.

options.label: Auto cancellation of all trades after market close
options.feedback: Trades are not auto cancelled after close by default.

miniCheck.prompt: How should agents coach advisers on settlement awareness?

options.label: Confirm the settlement cut off while reviewing the trade ticket
options.feedback: Correct - reinforcing cut offs prevents missed settlements (page 13).

options.label: Suggest checking the cash ladder and sweep rules before submitting
options.feedback: Correct - cash sweeps ensure funds are ready for settlement (page 13).

options.label: Advise waiting for the nightly email summary before calling clients
options.feedback: Nightly summaries should not replace proactive communication.

options.label: Tell advisers to disable compliance prompts for faster entry
options.feedback: Compliance prompts should remain enabled.

miniCheck.prompt: True or false: Always verify cash availability and sweep behaviour before trade entry.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

example.label: Managed account trade support
example.scenario: An adviser wants to validate pending managed account instructions before market close.
example.application: Guide them to the pending trades filter, confirm cash availability, and alert them to the settlement cut off.

takeaways: Always verify cash availability and sweep behaviour before trade entry.
Use the activity timeline to troubleshoot missing or delayed orders.
Corporate action follow ups need clear ownership and documented cut offs.
nextActions: Refresh the trading workspace sandbox each week to stay familiar with UI changes.
Document any recurring trade escalation patterns for the product team.

modules.title: Reporting and Analytics Deep Dive
objectives: Show how to configure custom date ranges and on demand report exports.
Explain look-through analytics including sector, currency, and exposure dashboards.
Coach advisers on sharing insights without exporting sensitive data.
modules.explanation: Explore interactive reporting, custom date ranges, and look-through analytics so advisers can self serve complex performance questions.
procedureSteps: Clarify the reporting outcome the adviser wants and the target audience.
Demonstrate the custom date selector and saving favourite layouts.
Review sharing options, PDF exports, and permission-aware distribution.
edgeCases: Adviser cannot see a client in the family group dashboard - confirm they have visibility permissions.
Report takes longer than expected - suggest reducing data columns or using scheduled exports.
Client requests raw data - remind advisers of data minimisation and permission rules.

miniCheck.prompt: Which feature differentiates Edge reporting from the legacy platforms?

options.label: Custom date range selection with instant visual updates
options.feedback: Correct - custom ranges render instantly on Edge (page 18).

options.label: Reports restricted to quarter end periods
options.feedback: Edge removed the quarter end restriction.

options.label: Mandatory overnight batches to generate PDF outputs
options.feedback: Reports now generate on demand.

options.label: Removal of look-through analytics
options.feedback: Look-through analytics are a headline addition.

miniCheck.prompt: How should agents respond to advisers requesting visibility beyond their permission set?

options.label: Confirm whether a family group permission exists before sharing data
options.feedback: Correct - visibility is permission based (page 19).

options.label: Offer to email raw CSV exports regardless of permissions
options.feedback: Raw exports should never bypass permissions.

options.label: Suggest using the adviser branded PDF export instead
options.feedback: Correct - branded PDFs respect permissions and are client safe (page 19).

options.label: Encourage sharing screenshots from internal admin consoles
options.feedback: Screenshots risk leaking restricted information.

miniCheck.prompt: True or false: Custom ranges and look-through dashboards reduce manual spreadsheet work.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

example.label: Family group insight
example.scenario: An adviser wants to show a family group their aggregate currency exposure during a review meeting.
example.application: Demonstrate the look-through dashboard, set a custom date range, and export the adviser branded PDF for the meeting.

takeaways: Custom ranges and look-through dashboards reduce manual spreadsheet work.
Reporting permissions remain enforced even when exporting branded outputs.
Clarify the question first, then guide advisers to the quickest reporting path.
nextActions: Save personal reporting presets so you can demo them quickly on calls.
Collect adviser feedback on dashboard latency for the analytics squad.

modules.title: Security, Access, and Authentication
objectives: Explain the July 2025 authentication refresh and why the countdown timer was removed.
Clarify MFA options, reset flows, and when to hand off to security operations.
Coach advisers on managing team access, delegations, and offboarding.
modules.explanation: Cover multi-factor authentication, session management, and adviser access governance in the redesigned login experience.
procedureSteps: Verify caller identity and authority before discussing access changes.
Walk through MFA reset steps and the security incident escalation matrix.
Record access changes and confirm adviser acknowledgement via email.
edgeCases: Adviser struggles with MFA codes - confirm device sync and offer back up methods.
Caller requests bypassing MFA for a temporary user - reiterate policy and escalate only if criteria met.
Team forgot to disable access for a departing staff member - guide them through role removal and log the confirmation.

miniCheck.prompt: Why did Edge remove the login countdown timer?

options.label: To reduce anxiety and improve accessibility for users
options.feedback: Correct - the redesign focused on calmer login experiences (page 22).

options.label: Because MFA codes no longer expire
options.feedback: MFA codes still expire; the timer change is unrelated.

options.label: Due to ASIC enforcing a maximum session length
options.feedback: ASIC limits are not cited as the reason.

options.label: To allow guest logins without authentication
options.feedback: Guest logins are not part of the program.

miniCheck.prompt: Which steps belong in the emergency access escalation path?

options.label: Verify client impact and document the service ticket number
options.feedback: Correct - documentation is mandatory (page 21).

options.label: Bypass security review to restore access instantly
options.feedback: Bypasses are not permitted.

options.label: Notify the security operations mailbox and quote the Severity matrix
options.feedback: Correct - severity alignment keeps the incident traceable (page 21).

options.label: Share passwords over the phone if the adviser insists
options.feedback: Passwords must never be shared verbally.

miniCheck.prompt: True or false: Security resets require identity verification before any change is made.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

example.label: MFA reset triage
example.scenario: An adviser lost their authentication device on a roadshow and needs urgent access.
example.application: Confirm identity, guide them through backup MFA setup, and log the reset reference in the case record.

takeaways: Security resets require identity verification before any change is made.
The login redesign focused on calmer UX while keeping MFA mandatory.
Escalation paths must be documented with severity references.
nextActions: Review the security escalation matrix once per week.
Update local crib notes with the latest MFA backup instructions.

modules.title: Superannuation and Pension Functionality
objectives: Explain pension payment setup including minimum drawdowns and COR enforcement.
Clarify contribution caps, SG rate changes, and how Edge monitors limits.
Guide advisers on adjusting pension schedules and documenting client confirmation.
modules.explanation: Manage pension schedules, contribution caps, and condition of release safeguards for retirement clients.
procedureSteps: Confirm COR status and pension objectives before making any changes.
Review current payment frequency, bank details, and year to date totals.
Send a wrap up email summarising adjustments and next review dates.
edgeCases: COR shows Pending - explain why payment changes are blocked until status is Met.
Client asks about upcoming SG increase - confirm the 12 percent rate from July 2025.
Adviser wants a lump sum outside caps - outline tax implications and escalate if needed.

miniCheck.prompt: Which factor must be verified before altering pension payments?

options.label: Condition of release status is Met
options.feedback: Correct - payment changes are blocked until COR is Met (page 23).

options.label: The account has more than $50,000 cash
options.feedback: Cash balance alone is not a blocker.

options.label: The adviser has a marketing campaign running
options.feedback: Campaigns do not affect pension adjustments.

options.label: ATO exempted the client from annual reporting
options.feedback: Exemptions are not mentioned.

miniCheck.prompt: What should advisers communicate when increasing pension payment frequency?

options.label: Review year to date vs minimum drawdown before confirming
options.feedback: Correct - year to date tracking prevents breaches (page 24).

options.label: Confirm new bank details and cut off dates with the client
options.feedback: Correct - banking details and timing must be reconfirmed (page 24).

options.label: Advise that condition of release resets automatically
options.feedback: Condition of release does not reset automatically.

options.label: Skip documentation if the adviser knows the client well
options.feedback: Documentation is always required.

miniCheck.prompt: True or false: Condition of release is the gating factor for any pension adjustment.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

example.label: Pension schedule change
example.scenario: A retiree wants to shift from quarterly to monthly payments while staying above the minimum drawdown.
example.application: Check COR status, review year to date totals, confirm bank details, and send the adviser a written summary of the change.

takeaways: Condition of release is the gating factor for any pension adjustment.
Contribution caps and SG rises must be explained in plain language.
Document every change and confirm adviser acknowledgement in writing.
nextActions: Refresh on the pension minimum table at the start of each month.
Keep a template wrap up email ready for pension change confirmations.

modules.title: Insurance Product Enhancements
objectives: Summarise the July 2025 insurance upgrades and transfer process improvements.
Explain advice fee consent consolidation and required disclosures.
Coach advisers on responding to occupation change underwriting reviews.
modules.explanation: Cover insurance transfer upgrades, advice fee consent changes, and occupation based underwriting updates.
procedureSteps: Identify the insurance request type and confirm policy ownership.
Review consent requirements, supporting documents, and expected turnaround.
Escalate complex underwriting cases to the insurance support team with context.
edgeCases: Occupation change triggers underwriting review - gather new declarations before escalating.
Adviser wants to bundle multiple advice documents - explain the multi document consent process.
Client requests insurer transfer without replacement cover - clarify risks and compliance expectations.

miniCheck.prompt: What benefit does the multi document consent uplift deliver?

options.label: Allows several advice documents in one consolidated consent request
options.feedback: Correct - July 2025 introduced multi document consent (page 27).

options.label: Removes the need for client signatures entirely
options.feedback: Signatures remain mandatory.

options.label: Automatically approves all advice fees up to $10,000
options.feedback: Fee approvals are still assessed case by case.

options.label: Eliminates cooling off periods on replacement cover
options.feedback: Cooling off periods still apply.

miniCheck.prompt: Which steps help manage an insurance occupation change review?

options.label: Collect the new occupation details and remuneration band
options.feedback: Correct - underwriters require current occupation data (page 28).

options.label: Submit the request without supporting documents to save time
options.feedback: Supporting documents are required for underwriting.

options.label: Explain typical insurer turnaround so the adviser can set client expectations
options.feedback: Correct - expectation setting is a key coaching point (page 28).

options.label: Promise that premiums will not change
options.feedback: Premium outcomes cannot be guaranteed.

miniCheck.prompt: True or false: Consent consolidation simplifies adviser workflows but still needs full disclosure.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

example.label: Occupation review
example.scenario: An adviser reports a client moving from a desk role to site supervision and needs to know how premiums may change.
example.application: Capture the new occupation details, submit the underwriting request with supporting documents, and provide the insurer turnaround estimate.

takeaways: Consent consolidation simplifies adviser workflows but still needs full disclosure.
Underwriting reviews hinge on precise occupation and remuneration updates.
Always document insurer timeframes and follow up promises in case notes.
nextActions: Review the insurance escalation contacts list at least monthly.
Update your macro for summarising consent requirements in follow up emails.

modules.title: Common Adviser and Client Queries
objectives: Locate and personalise the top ten adviser response scripts.
Balance empathy and clarity when delivering scripted answers.
Know when to pivot from a script to live troubleshooting or escalation.
modules.explanation: Use the curated scripts to answer high frequency questions on digital access, reporting, transfers, and escalation etiquette.
procedureSteps: Listen for the query archetype before opening the relevant script.
Personalise the greeting and confirm context so the script feels tailored.
Offer a concise next step and document the resolution in the service record.
edgeCases: Adviser interrupts the script - summarise their concern and jump to the relevant step.
Client hears policy language - translate the script into conversational wording.
Query falls outside scripted scope - acknowledge limits and escalate appropriately.

miniCheck.prompt: What is the first action when using a scripted response?

options.label: Confirm the caller context and align the script before reading
options.feedback: Correct - alignment comes before reading verbatim (page 29).

options.label: Read the script word for word without pause
options.feedback: Scripts should be personalised.

options.label: Send the script via email instead of speaking
options.feedback: Live conversations need spoken responses.

options.label: Transfer the call to a supervisor
options.feedback: Supervisors are only needed for escalations.

miniCheck.prompt: How can agents keep scripted answers empathetic?

options.label: Paraphrase the core issue before giving the solution
options.feedback: Correct - paraphrasing shows active listening (page 29).

options.label: Use the caller name once near the end
options.feedback: Names should be used naturally throughout.

options.label: Highlight what changed in Edge that resolves the issue
options.feedback: Correct - linking improvements builds credibility (page 29).

options.label: Avoid offering follow up documentation
options.feedback: Follow up documentation reinforces understanding.

miniCheck.prompt: True or false: Scripts are a starting point that must be personalised to the caller.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

example.label: Reporting script
example.scenario: A practice manager calls about delayed reporting and expects the legacy overnight delay.
example.application: Acknowledge the old limitation, share the instant reporting upgrade, and invite them to try the saved layout feature while on the call.

takeaways: Scripts are a starting point that must be personalised to the caller.
Connecting scripts to recent platform improvements builds confidence.
Document the exact script used and any deviations for quality reviews.
nextActions: Review two scripts per day until they feel natural to deliver.
Capture new question patterns so script authors can update content.

modules.title: Agent Response to Complaints and Escalations
objectives: Classify incidents using Severity 1 to 3 definitions and triggers.
Execute the complaint response framework including acknowledgement and next steps.
Document recovery actions, owners, and follow up cadence in the case record.
modules.explanation: Follow the severity matrix, response scripts, and recovery commitments when handling complaints or escalations.
procedureSteps: Identify severity based on impact, breadth, and regulatory risk.
Acknowledge the emotion, restate the issue, and outline immediate actions.
Log the escalation pathway, owners, and agreed follow up times.
edgeCases: Caller demands executive escalation - follow the severity triggers before looping in leadership.
Multiple stakeholders involved - clarify who owns updates and when they will occur.
Regulatory references raised - notify compliance and record the artefacts shared.

miniCheck.prompt: What differentiates a Severity 1 incident?

options.label: Platform wide outage or breach needing immediate CTO and Service Desk engagement
options.feedback: Correct - Severity 1 covers critical outages or breaches (page 34).

options.label: Any incident where the client sounds upset
options.feedback: Emotional tone alone does not define severity.

options.label: Requests to change login preferences
options.feedback: Login changes are routine service requests.

options.label: Adviser asking about delayed paperwork
options.feedback: Delays alone may be Severity 2 or 3 depending on impact.

miniCheck.prompt: Which steps belong in the recovery outline you provide to callers?

options.label: Name the action owner and timeframe for the next update
options.feedback: Correct - transparency builds trust (page 33).

options.label: Avoid summarising the issue to save time
options.feedback: Summaries confirm shared understanding.

options.label: Explain any compensating controls or temporary workarounds
options.feedback: Correct - workarounds reduce impact (page 33).

options.label: Promise resolution within 24 hours regardless of scope
options.feedback: Do not promise unrealistic resolution times.

miniCheck.prompt: True or false: Severity levels dictate which stakeholders and channels become involved.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

example.label: Severity calibration
example.scenario: A financial planner reports a trading outage affecting five households and requests executive escalation.
example.application: Classify the incident as Severity 1, engage the Service Desk and CTO bridge, and confirm the follow up cadence with the adviser.

takeaways: Severity levels dictate which stakeholders and channels become involved.
Every complaint conversation needs acknowledgement, restatement, and clear next actions.
Accurate case notes keep teams aligned during fast moving incidents.
nextActions: Review the severity matrix before your next shift to keep triggers fresh.
Shadow an experienced escalation agent to observe live recovery conversations.

modules.title: Self-Service Promotion Strategy
objectives: Identify the self-service tools most relevant to adviser personas.
Coach advisers on the What Changed banner, digital forms, and knowledge base navigation.
Measure adoption using available telemetry and feedback loops.
modules.explanation: Promote Edge digital tools, highlight upcoming features, and coach advisers on adopting self-service workflows.
procedureSteps: Ask how the adviser currently accesses updates or submits requests.
Demo the relevant self-service feature and agree on a trial action.
Schedule a follow up to capture adoption feedback or blockers.
edgeCases: Adviser prefers email submissions - show how digital forms reduce rework.
Caller missed the What Changed banner - explain how to subscribe to alerts.
Practice needs training for new staff - recommend the onboarding learning path.

miniCheck.prompt: Which tactic reinforces adoption of the What Changed banner?

options.label: Encourage advisers to pin the banner and review updates weekly
options.feedback: Correct - weekly review keeps teams current (page 35).

options.label: Advise ignoring the banner until quarterly reviews
options.feedback: Quarterly cadence is too slow for rapid releases.

options.label: Send physical mailers summarising updates
options.feedback: Mailers are not highlighted in the guide.

options.label: Disable the banner if advisers find it distracting
options.feedback: Disabling removes key update visibility.

miniCheck.prompt: How can agents track digital adoption momentum?

options.label: Monitor telemetry dashboards showing form submission volumes
options.feedback: Correct - telemetry helps quantify adoption (page 35).

options.label: Request qualitative feedback during wrap up calls
options.feedback: Correct - feedback pairs with telemetry for context (page 35).

options.label: Assume adoption if there are no complaints
options.feedback: Silence does not confirm adoption.

options.label: Rely solely on marketing email open rates
options.feedback: Email opens are not sufficient evidence.

miniCheck.prompt: True or false: Self-service promotion must be tailored to adviser workflows and benefits.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

example.label: Digital form pilot
example.scenario: A practice still emails paper based forms for contribution changes.
example.application: Demo the digital form, highlight status tracking, and schedule a follow up to review their first submission.

takeaways: Self-service promotion must be tailored to adviser workflows and benefits.
Telemetry plus qualitative feedback paints the full adoption picture.
Follow ups cement behaviour change and surface friction to remove.
nextActions: Review telemetry dashboards before weekly team huddles.
Capture common objections so enablement teams can refresh messaging.

modules.title: Team Contacts and Escalation Matrix
objectives: Identify the correct queue or squad for common escalation scenarios.
Explain when to use the real time bridge versus asynchronous channels.
Document handover notes that set receiving teams up for success.
modules.explanation: Navigate the escalation matrix, identify primary contacts, and coordinate handovers across operations, product, and compliance teams.
procedureSteps: Confirm severity and topic before selecting an escalation path.
Notify the appropriate contact channel and share concise case context.
Track acknowledgements and update the adviser on next touchpoint timing.
edgeCases: Multiple teams need to engage - clarify ownership and sequencing up front.
Contact unavailable - escalate to the alternate listed in the matrix.
Adviser bypasses process - restate the matrix and explain how it protects response times.

miniCheck.prompt: When should the real time bridge be activated?

options.label: For Severity 1 incidents that require live coordination
options.feedback: Correct - the bridge is reserved for Severity 1 (page 36).

options.label: For routine document follow ups
options.feedback: Routine follow ups belong in standard queues.

options.label: Whenever an adviser requests a callback
options.feedback: Callbacks alone do not justify the bridge.

options.label: For marketing announcements
options.feedback: Marketing updates use regular channels.

miniCheck.prompt: Which handover details are essential when logging an escalation?

options.label: Summary of the issue, severity, and desired outcome
options.feedback: Correct - context and desired outcome set receiving teams up (page 37).

options.label: Copy of adviser email threads
options.feedback: Correct - attaching evidence avoids duplicate discovery (page 37).

options.label: Personal opinions about the adviser
options.feedback: Personal opinions are inappropriate for handovers.

options.label: Assumptions about root cause without data
options.feedback: Stick to facts and observations.

miniCheck.prompt: True or false: Using the matrix correctly keeps critical incidents on track.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

example.label: Complex escalation
example.scenario: A Severity 2 data integrity incident needs analytics and migration squads involved.
example.application: Log the escalation with severity, attach supporting data, notify both squads, and confirm ownership before closing the loop with the adviser.

takeaways: Using the matrix correctly keeps critical incidents on track.
Complete handover notes reduce back and forth between squads.
Alternates exist for every contact to maintain coverage.
nextActions: Review matrix updates at the start of each week.
Shadow a real time bridge call to observe coordination best practices.

modules.title: Handling Difficult Calls and De-Escalation
objectives: Recognise emotional cues and apply the acknowledgement script.
Reframe issues neutrally before presenting options or decisions.
Confirm agreement and follow up commitments before wrapping the call.
modules.explanation: Apply the four step de-escalation framework to acknowledge emotion, reframe issues, and secure agreement on next steps.
procedureSteps: Let the caller finish, acknowledge their emotion, and avoid premature solutions.
Restate the issue using neutral language and outline available paths.
Agree on the next action owner, timeframe, and confirmation method.
edgeCases: Caller continues to vent - loop back to acknowledgement and reframe gently.
Adviser demands an outcome you cannot authorise - explain constraints and escalate appropriately.
Call risks going in circles - summarise progress, confirm next steps, and set a follow up time.

miniCheck.prompt: What is the first step in the de-escalation framework?

options.label: Acknowledge the emotion and show you heard their concern
options.feedback: Correct - acknowledgement comes before solutioning (page 38).

options.label: Offer compensation immediately
options.feedback: Compensation decisions come later if needed.

options.label: Transfer the call to a peer
options.feedback: Transfers are a last resort.

options.label: Start reciting policy clauses
options.feedback: Policy citations happen after empathy and reframing.

miniCheck.prompt: Which behaviours help secure agreement at the end of the call?

options.label: Summarise the agreed action and confirm the owner
options.feedback: Correct - clarity avoids missed expectations (page 40).

options.label: Check for adviser agreement before closing
options.feedback: Correct - shared agreement prevents rework (page 40).

options.label: Avoid restating timeframes to keep the call short
options.feedback: Timeframes must be restated.

options.label: Skip wrap up emails when the call was long
options.feedback: Wrap up emails remain important.

miniCheck.prompt: True or false: Acknowledgement and reframing are the foundation for productive calls.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

example.label: Escalated adviser
example.scenario: An adviser frustrated by prior delays calls demanding immediate resolution.
example.application: Acknowledge the frustration, restate the issue factually, propose the fastest path, and confirm the follow up time in writing.

takeaways: Acknowledgement and reframing are the foundation for productive calls.
Agreement on owners and timelines prevents escalation relapses.
Written confirmations reinforce verbal commitments.
nextActions: Practice the acknowledgement script with a peer during coaching.
Review two recorded calls that demonstrate effective de-escalation.

modules.title: Quality Assurance and Performance Monitoring
objectives: Describe the QA rubric dimensions and scoring scale.
Interpret scorecard trends to prioritise coaching conversations.
Use QA findings to reinforce best practice and close gaps.
modules.explanation: Understand the QA rubric, scorecard cadence, and how to coach peers using call and case insights.
procedureSteps: Review recent QA scores before conducting coaching or calibration.
Highlight strengths first, then discuss opportunities with concrete examples.
Agree on action items and track follow up progress in coaching notes.
edgeCases: Agent disagrees with a QA score - walk through evidence and invite reflection.
New behaviour trend emerges - log it for calibration review.
Scorecard shows recurring documentation gaps - provide templates or job aids.

miniCheck.prompt: Which dimension is highlighted in the QA rubric?

options.label: Accuracy and compliance of information shared
options.feedback: Correct - accuracy is a core rubric pillar (page 41).

options.label: Agent social media follower count
options.feedback: Social metrics are not part of QA.

options.label: Number of vacation days taken
options.feedback: Time off is unrelated to QA scoring.

options.label: Volume of small talk on calls
options.feedback: Small talk is not scored.

miniCheck.prompt: How should supervisors use QA data during coaching?

options.label: Lead with positive observations before discussing gaps
options.feedback: Correct - balanced feedback improves uptake (page 41).

options.label: Set clear action items with due dates and follow ups
options.feedback: Correct - action orientation closes gaps (page 41).

options.label: Share QA results only annually
options.feedback: Feedback should be timely.

options.label: Avoid written coaching notes to save time
options.feedback: Notes ensure accountability.

miniCheck.prompt: True or false: QA highlights both compliance and customer experience behaviours.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

example.label: QA coaching
example.scenario: An agent consistently misses documenting escalation triggers in case notes.
example.application: Review the QA rubric, show examples of complete notes, and set a follow up to review improvements.

takeaways: QA highlights both compliance and customer experience behaviours.
Coaching should be timely, specific, and action oriented.
Trend reporting feeds back into training and content updates.
nextActions: Attend the next QA calibration session to align scoring.
Capture coaching outcomes in the central tracker after each conversation.

modules.title: Regulatory and Compliance Landscape
objectives: Summarise key regulatory changes impacting Edge workflows in 2025.
Explain AML escalation triggers and required documentation standards.
Guide advisers on maintaining compliant advice fee consent records.
modules.explanation: Stay current on AML, advice fee consent, privacy obligations, and regulatory reporting tied to Edge operations.
procedureSteps: Verify adviser credentials and intent before sharing regulatory updates.
Review the relevant obligation, documentation needs, and escalation path.
Log any regulatory discussion in the case notes with references for audit.
edgeCases: Adviser proposes bypassing AML checks - restate mandatory verification steps.
Consent documentation incomplete - explain what evidence must be retained.
Client references ASIC requirements - provide the factual summary and offer to follow up with compliance.

miniCheck.prompt: Which item must be retained when processing advice fee consent?

options.label: Signed consent documents covering the relevant advice period
options.feedback: Correct - signed documents are mandatory (page 44).

options.label: A verbal confirmation without recording
options.feedback: Verbal confirmation alone is insufficient.

options.label: An agent personal diary entry
options.feedback: Personal notes do not satisfy compliance.

options.label: Screenshots of marketing brochures
options.feedback: Brochures are not consent evidence.

miniCheck.prompt: What triggers an AML escalation according to the guide?

options.label: Suspicious transaction patterns that do not align to known behaviour
options.feedback: Correct - unusual transactions must be escalated (page 44).

options.label: Client refusing to provide identification documents
options.feedback: Correct - refusal to provide ID triggers escalation (page 44).

options.label: Adviser requesting a marketing brochure
options.feedback: Marketing requests are not AML triggers.

options.label: Receiving positive feedback from a client
options.feedback: Positive feedback is unrelated to AML.

miniCheck.prompt: True or false: Compliance conversations must be factual and supported with documented evidence.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

example.label: Consent audit readiness
example.scenario: A licensee asks how to evidence multi document consent for an ASIC review.
example.application: Outline the required signed documents, note the retention period, and offer an export of consent history from Edge.

takeaways: Compliance conversations must be factual and supported with documented evidence.
AML triggers include both unusual transactions and refusal to provide ID.
Advice fee consent requires clear documentation of scope and timeframe.
nextActions: Review the compliance update bulletin each fortnight.
Maintain a quick reference list of documents needed for common audits.

modules.title: Ongoing Training and Enablement Calendar
objectives: Describe the quarterly enablement themes and their target outcomes.
Align internal squads on content delivery dates and responsibilities.
Communicate upcoming sessions to advisers with clear value propositions.
modules.explanation: Coordinate monthly enablement themes, align squads with delivery dates, and keep advisers informed about upcoming sessions.
procedureSteps: Review the enablement calendar and identify sessions relevant to the caller.
Confirm presenters, materials, and audience segments before promoting events.
Document adviser registrations and follow up with recordings or resources.
edgeCases: Session capacity fills quickly - offer waitlist options and recorded content.
Topic shifts due to regulatory change - notify registrants promptly.
Adviser requests bespoke training - gather requirements and liaise with enablement.

miniCheck.prompt: How should agents promote upcoming enablement sessions?

options.label: Connect the session theme to specific adviser outcomes
options.feedback: Correct - framing value drives attendance (page 45).

options.label: Send calendar invites without context
options.feedback: Context is necessary to secure interest.

options.label: Share internal planning documents
options.feedback: Internal plans should stay internal.

options.label: Promise CE credits without confirmation
options.feedback: Only promise credits once confirmed.

miniCheck.prompt: Which follow ups reinforce training value?

options.label: Send recordings and key resources after the session
options.feedback: Correct - resources extend impact (page 45).

options.label: Collect feedback and share it with content owners
options.feedback: Correct - feedback loops improve future sessions (page 45).

options.label: Ignore attendance data
options.feedback: Attendance trends should be tracked.

options.label: Remove sessions once they pass to avoid clutter
options.feedback: Past sessions should remain accessible via recordings.

miniCheck.prompt: True or false: Tie training invitations to tangible adviser benefits or efficiencies.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

example.label: Enablement promotion
example.scenario: An adviser asks for updates on upcoming portfolio reporting training.
example.application: Share the session objectives, confirm presenters, register the adviser, and promise to send the recording afterward.

takeaways: Tie training invitations to tangible adviser benefits or efficiencies.
Follow ups with resources and surveys close the enablement loop.
Accurate attendance tracking informs future capacity planning.
nextActions: Review the enablement calendar during weekly standup.
Prepare quick summaries for the next two sessions to share on calls.

modules.title: Feedback Loop and Continuous Improvement
objectives: Describe the feedback intake channels and tagging structure.
Explain how feedback flows into backlog grooming and sprint planning.
Close the loop with advisers once changes ship or workarounds exist.
modules.explanation: Capture, categorise, and action adviser feedback through sprint reviews, content updates, and release notes.
procedureSteps: Log feedback with persona, impact, and urgency tags for prioritisation.
Share high impact themes in weekly triage with product and operations.
Notify advisers when their feedback results in fixes or workarounds.
edgeCases: Duplicate feedback across channels - consolidate entries to avoid over counting.
Adviser requests status updates - consult the backlog tracker before responding.
Feedback cannot be actioned immediately - share interim workarounds or next review date.

miniCheck.prompt: Which detail must every feedback submission include?

options.label: Persona or segment impacted along with the described issue
options.feedback: Correct - persona tagging aids prioritisation (page 46).

options.label: Agent personal opinion about the feature
options.feedback: Personal opinions are optional at best.

options.label: Internal team hierarchy charts
options.feedback: Hierarchy charts are unrelated.

options.label: A marketing tagline suggestion
options.feedback: Taglines are not required.

miniCheck.prompt: How do agents close the loop once feedback ships?

options.label: Notify the adviser that raised the feedback with release details
options.feedback: Correct - closing the loop builds trust (page 47).

options.label: Update knowledge base articles or scripts if behaviour changed
options.feedback: Correct - collateral must match new behaviour (page 47).

options.label: Delete the original feedback record
options.feedback: Records should be kept for history.

options.label: Avoid sharing release notes to limit expectations
options.feedback: Release notes help set expectations.

miniCheck.prompt: True or false: Structured tagging ensures feedback reaches the right squads quickly.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

example.label: Feedback follow up
example.scenario: An adviser reported missing tax lot visibility, and the product squad shipped an enhancement.
example.application: Log the fix as shipped, update relevant scripts, and email the adviser to thank them for the insight.

takeaways: Structured tagging ensures feedback reaches the right squads quickly.
Closing the loop converts feedback moments into loyalty gains.
Documentation updates must accompany product improvements.
nextActions: Review last week feedback themes during team huddles.
Verify that scripts reflect the latest fixes before your next shift.

modules.title: Additional Scenarios and Edge Cases
objectives: Identify uncommon scenarios documented in the training guide and their owners.
Explain the rapid response steps for outage, data, and insurance edge cases.
Practice scenario based conversations to build confidence under pressure.
modules.explanation: Prepare for rare but high impact scenarios spanning outage bridges, complex transfers, and specialised client needs.
procedureSteps: Scan the scenario index to confirm ownership and severity alignment.
Use the provided playbooks to structure logistics, communication, and follow up.
Record lessons learned after each scenario to inform future playbooks.
edgeCases: Unexpected outage outside business hours - engage the bridge and update the status page.
Transfer stuck due to overseas custodian - coordinate with the specialist team and manage adviser expectations.
Insurance claim with medical complexity - gather additional disclosures before escalating.

miniCheck.prompt: What should agents reference first when a rare scenario surfaces?

options.label: The scenario index to identify owners and severity
options.feedback: Correct - the index is the starting point (page 48).

options.label: Personal memory of previous incidents
options.feedback: Personal memory may be incomplete.

options.label: Marketing materials
options.feedback: Marketing content does not guide scenarios.

options.label: External social media posts
options.feedback: Social posts are not official guidance.

miniCheck.prompt: Which behaviours help teams learn from edge cases?

options.label: Document lessons learned and feed them into playbook updates
options.feedback: Correct - documentation improves future responses (page 48).

options.label: Share scenario recaps during weekly standups
options.feedback: Correct - sharing keeps teams ready (page 48).

options.label: Avoid talking about challenging cases to reduce anxiety
options.feedback: Avoidance reduces readiness.

options.label: Rely on memory instead of playbooks
options.feedback: Playbooks exist to reduce risk.

miniCheck.prompt: True or false: Scenario readiness starts with knowing where to find owners and playbooks.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

example.label: After hours outage
example.scenario: The platform experiences a login outage at 8pm with multiple advisers impacted.
example.application: Activate the real time bridge, post to the status channel, and coordinate updates every 15 minutes until resolved.

takeaways: Scenario readiness starts with knowing where to find owners and playbooks.
Post incident reviews must feed back into documentation.
Frequent rehearsal keeps agents calm during real incidents.
nextActions: Review one scenario playbook per week during downtime.
Participate in the next incident simulation exercise.

modules.title: Communication Best Practices
objectives: Structure communications using acknowledgement, clarity, and next steps.
Tailor tone for advisers, end investors, and internal stakeholders.
Use status updates and wrap up emails to reinforce trust.
modules.explanation: Deliver clear, empathetic, and action oriented communications across email, phone, and bridge updates.
procedureSteps: Identify the audience and desired outcome before crafting the message.
Use the ACE (acknowledge, clarify, execute) structure to frame communications.
Confirm receipt and invite follow up questions to keep dialogue open.
edgeCases: Adviser misreads urgency - restate the impact and critical timelines.
Investor needs reassurance - balance empathy with factual updates.
Internal teams require quick bullet summaries - share highlights with clear actions.

miniCheck.prompt: What does the ACE structure stand for?

options.label: Acknowledge, Clarify, Execute
options.feedback: Correct - ACE underpins the communication model (page 49).

options.label: Ask, Confirm, Escalate
options.feedback: Ask, Confirm, Escalate is not the documented model.

options.label: Assess, Coach, Evaluate
options.feedback: Assess, Coach, Evaluate relates to training.

options.label: Align, Challenge, Exit
options.feedback: Align, Challenge, Exit is not referenced.

miniCheck.prompt: Which behaviours keep adviser emails effective?

options.label: Lead with the acknowledgement before outlining updates
options.feedback: Correct - acknowledgement shows empathy (page 49).

options.label: Include clear next actions and owners
options.feedback: Correct - clarity on next steps builds trust (page 49).

options.label: Use dense paragraphs without headings
options.feedback: Dense paragraphs reduce clarity.

options.label: Avoid stating timelines to stay flexible
options.feedback: Timelines are essential to manage expectations.

miniCheck.prompt: True or false: ACE keeps communications focused and empathetic.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

example.label: Wrap up email
example.scenario: After resolving a reporting query, the adviser requests a summary for their records.
example.application: Send an ACE structured email acknowledging the query, clarifying the fix, and listing future actions.

takeaways: ACE keeps communications focused and empathetic.
Lead with acknowledgement before diving into technical detail.
Assign owners and timeframes in every wrap up.
nextActions: Draft ACE templates for common adviser follow ups.
Review two recent emails against the ACE checklist.

modules.title: Final Checklists and Reference Tools
objectives: Use the outbound call, transfer, and escalation checklists to drive consistency.
Reference decision trees for severity, pension changes, and de-escalation cues.
Keep cheat sheets accessible for thresholds, do and do not lists, and triggers.
modules.explanation: Leverage final checklists, cheat sheets, and decision trees to maintain quality and speed across Edge interactions.
procedureSteps: Open the relevant checklist before performing the task to confirm steps.
Tick off mandatory documentation fields and attach supporting artefacts.
Share the completed checklist summary in wrap up communications when applicable.
edgeCases: Checklist not updated after enhancements - note discrepancies for content owners.
Team forgets to reference decision trees - add quick links to personal dashboards.
Adviser questions threshold accuracy - quote the cheat sheet reference page.

miniCheck.prompt: Why are the final checklists critical for quality assurance?

options.label: They ensure mandatory documentation is not missed before closing a case
options.feedback: Correct - checklists protect completeness (page 50).

options.label: They replace the need for training
options.feedback: Checklists complement training but do not replace it.

options.label: They allow bypassing compliance reviews
options.feedback: Compliance reviews remain mandatory.

options.label: They generate marketing content automatically
options.feedback: Marketing content is unrelated.

miniCheck.prompt: How should decision trees be used during live calls?

options.label: Keep them visible and step through the decision flow with the caller
options.feedback: Correct - walking through the tree boosts accuracy (page 50).

options.label: Skip them to save time when the call is simple
options.feedback: Skipping risks missing important steps.
