options.label: Note any unexpected branches for future updates
options.feedback: Correct - feedback keeps decision trees current (page 50).

options.label: Share screenshots externally without context
options.feedback: Screenshots should not be shared externally.

miniCheck.prompt: True or false: Checklists, decision trees, and cheat sheets keep quality consistent.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

example.label: Checklist reinforcement
example.scenario: Before closing a pension adjustment case, an agent wants to ensure no documentation was skipped.
example.application: Open the final checklist, confirm each requirement is met, and reference the checklist in the wrap up email.

takeaways: Checklists, decision trees, and cheat sheets keep quality consistent.
Always surface discrepancies so content stays aligned with product changes.
Wrap ups should reference the tools used to build trust with advisers.
nextActions: Pin the most used checklists to your browser bookmarks.
Flag any outdated checklist items to the knowledge team immediately.

modules.title: Streaming Telemetry and Platform Monitoring
objectives: Describe the telemetry pipeline that replaced overnight batch monitoring.
Interpret key dashboards agents use during incident triage.
Communicate telemetry insights to advisers without exposing internal jargon.
modules.explanation: Explain how Edge streaming telemetry powers live dashboards, health monitoring, and proactive incident communication.
procedureSteps: Open the platform health dashboard at the start of every shift.
Correlate adviser reports with telemetry signals before declaring incidents.
Document telemetry references in case notes when sharing status updates.
edgeCases: Telemetry spike but no adviser calls yet - alert the bridge lead to prepare communications.
Adviser reports slowness but dashboards show green - gather detailed steps and browser info.
Dashboard alert persists after incident resolved - flag the data engineering squad.

miniCheck.prompt: What did streaming telemetry replace from the legacy platform?

options.label: Overnight batch health checks that delayed incident detection
options.feedback: Correct - batch based monitoring was replaced by streaming (page 2).

options.label: Proactive client communication
options.feedback: Communication remains the agent responsibility.

options.label: API integrations with adviser CRMs
options.feedback: APIs were expanded, not removed.

options.label: Corporate action processing
options.feedback: Corporate actions are unrelated to telemetry.

miniCheck.prompt: How should telemetry be used during incident updates?

options.label: Reference the dashboard trend to validate adviser reports
options.feedback: Correct - telemetry confirms impact (page 2).

options.label: Share raw internal dashboard screenshots externally
options.feedback: Internal dashboards should not be shared.

options.label: Record the telemetry reference in the case notes
options.feedback: Correct - documentation supports incident reviews (page 2).

options.label: Ignore telemetry when a single adviser calls
options.feedback: Telemetry should still be checked.

miniCheck.prompt: True or false: Streaming telemetry enables faster incident validation and response.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

example.label: Telemetry guided response
example.scenario: An adviser reports latency and the dashboard shows a spike in API errors.
example.application: Check the health dashboard, notify the real time lead, and share the validated status with the adviser.

takeaways: Streaming telemetry enables faster incident validation and response.
Agents should translate telemetry insights into plain language for advisers.
Documenting telemetry references supports post incident analysis.
nextActions: Review the health dashboard legend before each shift.
Subscribe to telemetry alert summaries for your squad.

modules.title: API Integration Playbook
objectives: List the major platforms with direct Edge API integrations.
Explain API onboarding requirements, authentication, and rate limits.
Escalate integration issues with the right diagnostic information.
modules.explanation: Support advisers using Edge APIs to connect CRMs, planning tools, and data warehouses.
procedureSteps: Identify the partner platform and integration objective.
Confirm the adviser has API credentials and understands the terms of use.
Capture error payloads or timestamps before escalating to the API squad.
edgeCases: Adviser lacks API credentials - direct them to the digital request form.
Integration throttled due to rate limits - explain batch scheduling best practices.
Data mismatch reported - gather sample payloads and log an investigation ticket.

miniCheck.prompt: Which adviser platforms have direct Edge API connections?

options.label: Iress and AdviserLogic
options.feedback: Correct - both are named API partners (page 2).

options.label: Netwealth API gateway
options.feedback: Correct - Netwealth connectivity is listed (page 2).

options.label: Random social media tools
options.feedback: Social media tools are not referenced.

options.label: Legacy FirstWrap batch feeds only
options.feedback: Batch feeds were replaced by live APIs.

miniCheck.prompt: What should be collected before escalating an API issue?

options.label: Error payloads, timestamps, and the endpoint being called
options.feedback: Correct - diagnostics enable faster resolution (page 2).

options.label: A screenshot of the adviser desktop wallpaper
options.feedback: Wallpapers are irrelevant.

options.label: The agent star rating
options.feedback: Star ratings are not used.

options.label: Marketing preferences of the adviser
options.feedback: Marketing preferences are unrelated.

miniCheck.prompt: True or false: API support begins with verifying partner and credential readiness.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

example.label: API troubleshooting
example.scenario: An adviser automation fails when sending trade instructions from their CRM.
example.application: Gather the endpoint, error code, and timestamp, then escalate to the API squad while offering manual workaround guidance.

takeaways: API support begins with verifying partner and credential readiness.
Detailed diagnostics reduce back and forth with technical squads.
Advisers appreciate clear guidance on rate limits and best practices.
nextActions: Review the API onboarding checklist this week.
Save a template email requesting error payloads from advisers.

modules.title: Digital Identity Verification Essentials
objectives: Explain how Edge verifies identity for individuals, trustees, and directors.
List accepted document types and certification requirements.
Handle exceptions or failures using the manual review workflow.
modules.explanation: Master the digital identity capture steps, document requirements, and fallback processes for Edge onboarding.
procedureSteps: Confirm entity type and required documents before starting the digital capture.
Guide advisers through uploading certified documents and linking signatories.
Trigger manual review when automated checks fail and set follow up expectations.
edgeCases: Document upload fails - confirm file size, format, and retry steps.
International trustee without local ID - escalate to manual review with alternate documents.
Name mismatch across documents - request supporting evidence before proceeding.

miniCheck.prompt: Which documents must be certified for trust onboarding?

options.label: Trust deed and trustee identification documents
options.feedback: Correct - both must be certified (page 4).

options.label: Marketing brochures
options.feedback: Brochures are optional, not mandatory.

options.label: Call recordings
options.feedback: Recordings are not part of identity capture.

options.label: Investment questionnaires
options.feedback: Questionnaires support suitability, not identity.

miniCheck.prompt: How should failed electronic verification be handled?

options.label: Trigger manual review and advise on expected turnaround
options.feedback: Correct - manual review picks up failed checks (page 5).

options.label: Proceed anyway to avoid delays
options.feedback: Proceeding without verification breaches policy.

options.label: Collect alternative documents like certified passports or driver licences
options.feedback: Correct - alternative documents support verification (page 5).

options.label: Delete the application and ask the adviser to start over
options.feedback: Restarting wastes time and is not required.

miniCheck.prompt: True or false: Digital identity steps vary by entity type, so confirm requirements early.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

example.label: Manual review setup
example.scenario: A trust director fails the electronic verification due to an overseas passport.
example.application: Collect certified passport copies, trigger manual review, and set the expectation for turnaround time.

takeaways: Digital identity steps vary by entity type, so confirm requirements early.
Certified documents remain essential for trusts and some SMSFs.
Manual review workflows keep onboarding moving when automation fails.
nextActions: Update your ID verification cheat sheet with acceptable documents.
Practice explaining manual review timelines during role play.

modules.title: Condition of Release Governance
objectives: Define each condition of release status in the Edge interface.
Explain documentation requirements when COR is pending or denied.
Coach advisers on communicating COR impacts to retirees.
modules.explanation: Ensure pension changes comply with condition of release rules, documentation, and audit trails.
procedureSteps: Check the COR widget before processing any pension request.
Collect or request missing documentation that proves eligibility.
Record COR status, supporting artefacts, and next review dates in case notes.
edgeCases: COR pending - outline what evidence is missing and pause changes until received.
Adviser questions why Met is required - explain regulatory obligations in plain language.
Client experiences financial hardship - escalate for hardship assessment using the documented process.

miniCheck.prompt: What does the COR status Pending indicate?

options.label: Supporting documentation is outstanding or under review
options.feedback: Correct - Pending means evidence is still required (page 23).

options.label: Payments can proceed immediately
options.feedback: Pending prevents payment changes.

options.label: The client is exempt from COR rules
options.feedback: There is no exemption state.

options.label: The system has a bug
options.feedback: Pending reflects documentation state, not a bug.

miniCheck.prompt: Which records should be stored when COR transitions to Met?

options.label: Certified documents proving eligibility
options.feedback: Correct - documentation evidences compliance (page 23).

options.label: Agent personal notes only
options.feedback: Personal notes are insufficient.

options.label: Case notes summarising the change and follow up date
options.feedback: Correct - summarising the change keeps audits clear (page 23).

options.label: Marketing preferences
options.feedback: Marketing preferences are unrelated.

miniCheck.prompt: True or false: COR status governs every pension decision in Edge.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

example.label: COR documentation call
example.scenario: An adviser wants to increase pension payments but the status shows Pending.
example.application: Explain what documentation is missing, pause the change, and send a checklist of required evidence.

takeaways: COR status governs every pension decision in Edge.
Documentation must prove eligibility before payments can change.
Plain language explanations build adviser confidence in the controls.
nextActions: Review the COR documentation checklist with your team.
Create an email template for requesting missing COR evidence.

modules.title: Pension Adjustment Reviews
objectives: Review year to date drawdowns against minimum thresholds before changes.
Confirm banking details and payment cut offs when adjustments are requested.
Document adviser approvals and client confirmations for audit.
modules.explanation: Handle pension frequency, amount, and banking changes while protecting compliance and client outcomes.
procedureSteps: Open the pension dashboard to confirm YTD, minimum, and COR status.
Capture the requested change, confirm bank details, and note payment timing.
Send a wrap up email confirming changes and reminders for next review.
edgeCases: Payment falls below minimum - advise on catch up plan before year end.
Bank account mismatch - obtain updated banking instructions before actioning.
Adviser wants immediate lump sum - explain tax impact and escalate if needed.

miniCheck.prompt: Why must YTD drawdown be checked before changing schedules?

options.label: To ensure the member stays above the minimum drawdown requirement
options.feedback: Correct - minimum thresholds must be maintained (page 24).

options.label: To calculate adviser commissions
options.feedback: Commissions are unrelated to the check.

options.label: To unlock new marketing emails
options.feedback: Marketing emails are irrelevant.

options.label: To bypass condition of release rules
options.feedback: COR cannot be bypassed.

miniCheck.prompt: What should be confirmed after making a pension change?

options.label: Updated bank account details and next payment date
options.feedback: Correct - banking and timing must be confirmed (page 24).

options.label: That the adviser will inform the client in writing
options.feedback: Correct - written confirmation supports audit trails (page 24).

options.label: That condition of release resets automatically
options.feedback: COR does not reset automatically.

options.label: That no documentation is required for the change
options.feedback: Documentation remains essential.

miniCheck.prompt: True or false: Pension adjustments always start with COR status and YTD position.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

example.label: YTD check
example.scenario: A retiree wants to reduce payments mid year to preserve cash flow.
example.application: Review YTD drawdown, confirm the new schedule keeps them above minimum, and document the approval.

takeaways: Pension adjustments always start with COR status and YTD position.
Bank details, payment timing, and documentation must be reconfirmed.
Wrap up communications keep advisers aligned with the agreed change.
nextActions: Practice reviewing YTD and minimum values in the sandbox.
Refresh your email template library for pension adjustments.

modules.title: Managed Accounts Optimisation
objectives: Explain the managed account rebalancing cadence and drift thresholds.
Coach advisers on upgrade workflows and portfolio visibility tools.
Coordinate communications when managed account trades are paused or escalated.
modules.explanation: Support managed account upgrades, rebalancing rules, and communication strategies for high value portfolios.
procedureSteps: Confirm portfolio type, objective, and current drift before recommending actions.
Review upgrade requirements, permissions, and investor acknowledgements.
Schedule proactive updates when rebalances are delayed or rescheduled.
edgeCases: Drift exceeds 10 percent - explain the automated rebalance trigger and timing.
Adviser wants manual overrides - clarify governance and approval process.
Portfolio paused due to model change - communicate expected restart timing.

miniCheck.prompt: What triggers a managed account rebalance according to the guide?

options.label: Quarterly schedule or a drift beyond plus or minus 10 percent
options.feedback: Correct - both cadence and drift trigger rebalances (page 14).

options.label: Any adviser email regardless of drift
options.feedback: Emails alone do not trigger rebalances.

options.label: Marketing announcements
options.feedback: Marketing is unrelated.

options.label: Client birthday reminders
options.feedback: Birthdays are irrelevant.

miniCheck.prompt: How should delays in managed account rebalances be communicated?

options.label: Share the reason for the delay and the revised completion window
options.feedback: Correct - transparency manages expectations (page 14).

options.label: Provide interim reporting or workarounds if available
options.feedback: Correct - workarounds reduce adviser stress (page 14).

options.label: Avoid updating advisers until the rebalance is complete
options.feedback: Silence erodes trust.

options.label: Blame external markets without investigation
options.feedback: Blame without evidence is unhelpful.

miniCheck.prompt: True or false: Managed accounts follow defined cadence and drift rules to protect investors.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

example.label: Drift management
example.scenario: A family office practice sees drift beyond 10 percent and wants to know next steps.
example.application: Explain the automated rebalance process, confirm expected timing, and note the follow up commitment.

takeaways: Managed accounts follow defined cadence and drift rules to protect investors.
Upgrade workflows require clear permissions and investor acknowledgements.
Communication must stay proactive whenever trades deviate from schedule.
nextActions: Review the managed account policy summary before your next shift.
Build a reusable update template for drift related conversations.

modules.title: Insurance Claims Triage
objectives: Outline the documentation required for insurance claims and escalations.
Set expectations on insurer response times and medical review steps.
Track claim milestones and follow ups in the service record.
modules.explanation: Coordinate insurance claim submissions, medical updates, and communication cadences with advisers and insurers.
procedureSteps: Collect claim type, policy details, and supporting evidence from the adviser.
Liaise with the insurer, logging reference numbers and expected timelines.
Provide regular updates to the adviser, especially after medical assessments.
edgeCases: Incomplete medical forms - advise on required details before submitting.
Urgent financial need - explore interim hardship support while claim progresses.
Insurer requests additional evidence - coordinate with adviser to obtain promptly.

miniCheck.prompt: Which information must accompany an insurance claim escalation?

options.label: Policy number, claim type, and supporting documents
options.feedback: Correct - complete information speeds escalation (page 28).

options.label: Adviser favourite coffee order
options.feedback: Coffee preferences are irrelevant.

options.label: Marketing collateral
options.feedback: Marketing collateral is unrelated.

options.label: Internal staff rosters
options.feedback: Staff rosters are not needed.

miniCheck.prompt: How should advisers be coached on claim timelines?

options.label: Explain typical insurer turnaround for the claim type
options.feedback: Correct - expectation setting is essential (page 28).

options.label: Promise payment within 48 hours
options.feedback: Payments cannot be promised without insurer confirmation.

options.label: Clarify what medical reviews or additional information may be required
options.feedback: Correct - clarity reduces surprises (page 28).

options.label: Avoid providing updates until the claim is finalised
options.feedback: Regular updates maintain trust.

miniCheck.prompt: True or false: Complete documentation is the fastest path to claim progression.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

example.label: Complex claim
example.scenario: A claimant faces a prolonged medical review and the adviser needs guidance on keeping the client informed.
example.application: Share typical review timelines, confirm documents submitted, and set the next update time.

takeaways: Complete documentation is the fastest path to claim progression.
Transparent timelines and next steps reduce adviser and client anxiety.
Case notes should capture insurer references and promised updates.
nextActions: Review the insurance claim checklist today.
Create a template for claim status updates including next steps.

modules.title: Incident War Room Coordination
objectives: Explain the roles of bridge lead, comms lead, and technical leads during incidents.
Run incident cadences including status updates, action tracking, and post incident reviews.
Capture learnings and feed them into continuous improvement loops.
modules.explanation: Coordinate cross functional war room activities during Severity 1 and 2 incidents using structured playbooks.
procedureSteps: Activate the incident bridge and assign roles within the first minutes.
Maintain an action log with owners, blockers, and timestamps.
Schedule the post incident review and distribute notes to stakeholders.
edgeCases: Multiple incidents compete for attention - prioritise based on severity and impact.
Information overload - summarise decisions at the end of each cadence call.
Stakeholders join late - provide concise recaps without derailing the discussion.

miniCheck.prompt: What is the comms lead accountable for during an incident?

options.label: Publishing timely updates to advisers and internal stakeholders
options.feedback: Correct - comms lead owns stakeholder updates (page 33).

options.label: Running database failovers
options.feedback: Technical leads handle failovers.

options.label: Approving marketing campaigns
options.feedback: Marketing is unrelated.

options.label: Processing payroll adjustments
options.feedback: Payroll is unrelated to incidents.

miniCheck.prompt: Which elements belong in the incident action log?

options.label: Action description, owner, and timestamp
options.feedback: Correct - tracking ensures accountability (page 34).

options.label: Outstanding blockers and decision requests
options.feedback: Correct - blockers and decisions need visibility (page 34).

options.label: Personal opinions about squad performance
options.feedback: Keep logs factual.

options.label: Future marketing slogans
options.feedback: Marketing slogans are irrelevant.

miniCheck.prompt: True or false: War room structure keeps incidents productive and transparent.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

example.label: War room cadence
example.scenario: A trading outage requires updates every 15 minutes to a multi disciplinary team.
example.application: Assign roles, maintain the action log, deliver concise updates, and schedule the post incident review.

takeaways: War room structure keeps incidents productive and transparent.
Action logs with owners and blockers drive accountability.
Post incident reviews capture learnings for future improvements.
nextActions: Review the incident war room checklist before the next simulation.
Shadow a bridge call to observe cadence pacing.

modules.title: Analytics Storytelling for Advisers
objectives: Select the right dashboard or report to answer the adviser question.
Translate metrics into business outcomes and recommended actions.
Use visual cues and annotations to make analytics easy to digest.
modules.explanation: Convert data points from Edge analytics into compelling adviser narratives that drive action.
procedureSteps: Clarify the audience and decision the adviser needs to make.
Choose visuals that align with the story and annotate key points.
Validate interpretations with the adviser before circulating insights.
edgeCases: Data overload - focus on the metric that links directly to the adviser goal.
Conflicting conclusions - revisit filters and explain assumptions.
Stakeholders need executive summary - provide bullet highlights with context.

miniCheck.prompt: What is the first step when building an analytics story?

options.label: Understand the decision or question the adviser is trying to answer
options.feedback: Correct - start with the decision to be made (page 18).

options.label: Export every available chart
options.feedback: Exporting everything creates clutter.

options.label: Discuss marketing campaigns
options.feedback: Marketing is separate from analytics storytelling.

options.label: Skip clarifying assumptions
options.feedback: Assumptions must be clarified.

miniCheck.prompt: How can visuals be made easier to interpret?

options.label: Annotate key points directly on the chart
options.feedback: Correct - annotations focus attention (page 19).

options.label: Use consistent colour coding for like metrics
options.feedback: Correct - consistency supports readability (page 19).

options.label: Remove titles to reduce clutter
options.feedback: Titles help orientation.

options.label: Share raw data without commentary
options.feedback: Raw data alone is difficult to interpret.

miniCheck.prompt: True or false: Always anchor analytics to the decision the adviser must make.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

example.label: Performance insight
example.scenario: An adviser wants to explain sector exposure shifts to a high net worth client.
example.application: Use the look-through dashboard, annotate exposure changes, and recommend a follow up discussion on rebalancing.

takeaways: Always anchor analytics to the decision the adviser must make.
Annotations and consistent visuals keep attention on what matters.
Validate the narrative with the adviser before wider circulation.
nextActions: Create a template for annotating charts during live calls.
Collect examples of effective dashboards to reference during storytelling.

modules.title: Digital Adoption Coaching
objectives: Diagnose the adoption stage of an adviser or practice.
Apply behavioural nudges and success stories to motivate digital usage.
Track adoption metrics and celebrate progress with stakeholders.
modules.explanation: Coach advisers through behavioural change techniques that accelerate adoption of Edge digital tools.
procedureSteps: Ask probing questions to identify barriers to digital adoption.
Share relevant success stories and agree on a specific trial behaviour.
Review metrics after the trial and reinforce wins or address blockers.
edgeCases: Adviser distrusts automation - share case studies and offer guided practice.
Practice lacks resources - connect them with training or streamlined workflows.
Adviser forgets to use new tools - set calendar reminders or prompts.

miniCheck.prompt: Which approach supports advisers in the experimentation stage?

options.label: Set a single next step and schedule a quick follow up
options.feedback: Correct - small commitments drive momentum (page 35).

options.label: Overwhelm them with every feature at once
options.feedback: Too many features create friction.

options.label: Ignore telemetry to focus on anecdotes
options.feedback: Telemetry remains valuable.

options.label: Promise automation will remove all manual work
options.feedback: Avoid unrealistic promises.

miniCheck.prompt: How can progress be reinforced?

options.label: Share telemetry improvements with the adviser team
options.feedback: Correct - sharing wins builds momentum (page 35).

options.label: Celebrate small wins in wrap up emails
options.feedback: Correct - recognition reinforces change (page 35).

options.label: Avoid acknowledging progress until adoption is perfect
options.feedback: Early reinforcement is important.

options.label: Remove guidance once initial usage occurs
options.feedback: Continued coaching prevents regression.

miniCheck.prompt: True or false: Identify the adviser adoption stage before offering solutions.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

example.label: Behavioural nudge
example.scenario: A practice resists using the Edge digital consent form despite training.
example.application: Share a peer success story, set a goal to trial the form with one client, and follow up on the outcome.

takeaways: Identify the adviser adoption stage before offering solutions.
Stories and data together motivate behaviour change.
Celebrate progress early to lock in new habits.
nextActions: Track practice adoption metrics in your coaching log.
Collect two new success stories to share with hesitant advisers.

modules.title: Escalation Handover Craft
objectives: Structure handover summaries using context, impact, and desired outcome.
Attach critical artefacts so receiving teams can act without delay.
Confirm receipt and ownership changes during and after handover.
modules.explanation: Write crisp escalation handovers that enable downstream squads to respond quickly and accurately.
procedureSteps: Draft the handover using bullet points for context, impact, and request.
Attach evidence such as screenshots, documents, or call excerpts.
Follow up to confirm receipt and log the new owner in the case notes.
edgeCases: Receiving team requests clarification - respond quickly and update the summary.
Multiple squads involved - split handovers by workstream to avoid confusion.
Handover format deviates - use the standard template to maintain consistency.

miniCheck.prompt: Which element must every handover include?

options.label: Desired outcome or decision needed from the receiving team
options.feedback: Correct - desired outcome focuses the response (page 37).

options.label: Personal opinions about the adviser
options.feedback: Opinions do not belong in handovers.

options.label: Internal team gossip
options.feedback: Gossip is unprofessional and irrelevant.

options.label: Historical marketing campaign data
options.feedback: Marketing history is unrelated.

miniCheck.prompt: How should confirmation of ownership be handled?

options.label: Record the new owner in the case system once acknowledged
options.feedback: Correct - ownership tracking avoids confusion (page 37).

options.label: Notify the adviser of the new owner and next update time
options.feedback: Correct - advisers need to know who will contact them (page 37).

options.label: Assume ownership changed without confirmation
options.feedback: Always confirm ownership.

options.label: Remove the original agent from the case history
options.feedback: History should remain intact.

miniCheck.prompt: True or false: Structured handovers reduce delays and duplicate effort.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

example.label: Precision handover
example.scenario: A data migration escalation moves from the service team to analytics.
example.application: Summarise context, attach evidence, confirm analytics acceptance, and update the adviser with the new owner.

takeaways: Structured handovers reduce delays and duplicate effort.
Desired outcomes and attached artefacts keep teams focused.
Ownership changes must be confirmed internally and externally.
nextActions: Review the handover template with your team today.
Audit two recent handovers to ensure they include desired outcomes.

modules.title: Compliance Evidence Packaging
objectives: Identify the evidence regulators or licensees expect for common scenarios.
Package case notes, documents, and timelines into a coherent response.
Partner with compliance to submit accurate and timely packages.
modules.explanation: Assemble artefacts and narratives required for audits, regulatory reviews, and licensee queries.
procedureSteps: Clarify the audit scope, timeframe, and documentation checklist.
Export relevant Edge records and compile supporting notes.
Review the package with compliance before sending to external stakeholders.
edgeCases: Incomplete records - work with advisers to gather missing documentation quickly.
Short turnaround deadline - prioritise by risk and escalate if timeframes are unrealistic.
Sensitive data in logs - ensure redactions follow privacy policy before sharing.

miniCheck.prompt: What must be included when packaging advice fee evidence?

options.label: Signed consent, relevant correspondence, and transaction history
options.feedback: Correct - all three elements evidence compliance (page 44).

options.label: Agent personal opinions about the fee
options.feedback: Personal opinions are not evidence.

options.label: Marketing flyers for related products
options.feedback: Marketing material is irrelevant.

options.label: Internal chat jokes
options.feedback: Chats are not part of evidence unless relevant to the case.

miniCheck.prompt: How should sensitive data be handled in compliance packages?

options.label: Redact personal identifiers that are not required for the review
options.feedback: Correct - redact unnecessary personal data (page 45).

options.label: Log the redaction and rationale in the package summary
options.feedback: Correct - documenting redactions maintains transparency (page 45).

options.label: Send raw exports without review
options.feedback: Raw exports should be reviewed first.

options.label: Ignore privacy policy to save time
options.feedback: Privacy policy must always be followed.

miniCheck.prompt: True or false: Evidence packages must align with regulatory expectations and privacy policy.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

example.label: Audit preparation
example.scenario: A licensee audit requests evidence for multiple advice fee consent renewals.
example.application: Collect signed consent files, extract Edge transaction records, summarise timelines, and have compliance review before delivery.

takeaways: Evidence packages must align with regulatory expectations and privacy policy.
Comprehensive documentation reduces back and forth during audits.
Compliance partnerships ensure submissions are accurate and timely.
nextActions: Review the audit evidence checklist this week.
Create a standard cover note template for evidence packages.

modules.title: Data Migration Readiness
objectives: Review migration milestones and prerequisites with adviser practices.
Confirm data quality checks that minimise post migration remediation.
Explain performance history reconstruction timelines and updates.
modules.explanation: Prepare adviser practices for data migration by validating records, communicating timelines, and managing performance history expectations.
procedureSteps: Share the migration timeline and confirm practice readiness checkpoints.
Guide advisers through data validation tasks before migration cut over.
Schedule post migration follow ups to confirm history reconstruction completion.
edgeCases: Practice misses validation tasks - provide a catch up plan and escalate if deadlines risk migration.
Performance history still rebuilding - quote the 2-5 week window and log updates.
Unexpected data discrepancies - capture examples and escalate to migration specialists.

miniCheck.prompt: How long can performance history reconstruction take after migration?

options.label: Between two and five weeks depending on complexity
options.feedback: Correct - reconstruction may take two to five weeks (page 8).

options.label: Less than 24 hours for every account
options.feedback: 24 hour turnaround is not guaranteed.

options.label: Exactly eight weeks regardless of portfolio
options.feedback: Eight weeks is not stated.

options.label: Only when clients request it
options.feedback: Reconstruction is part of the migration process.

miniCheck.prompt: Which actions prepare a practice for migration?

options.label: Complete data validation tasks before cut over
options.feedback: Correct - validation prevents issues (page 10).

options.label: Communicate key dates and downtime windows to stakeholders
options.feedback: Correct - proactive communication manages expectations (page 10).

options.label: Disable all trading for a month
options.feedback: Trading disablement is not required a month out.

options.label: Avoid mentioning potential downtime
options.feedback: Downtime should be communicated.

miniCheck.prompt: True or false: Migration readiness combines data validation, communication, and follow ups.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

example.label: Migration briefing
example.scenario: A practice wants assurance that their historical performance data will be preserved.
example.application: Review the migration milestones, explain reconstruction timelines, and schedule a follow up check in after cut over.

takeaways: Migration readiness combines data validation, communication, and follow ups.
Performance history reconstruction may take weeks; set expectations early.
Escalate discrepancies with clear examples and timestamps.
nextActions: Refresh your migration milestone tracker before upcoming cut overs.
Prepare a standard update email for practices approaching migration.

modules.title: Voice of Customer Operations
objectives: Collect voice of customer signals across calls, surveys, and telemetry.
Prioritise themes using impact and effort scoring for action planning.
Share outcomes with advisers to demonstrate listening and responsiveness.
modules.explanation: Translate voice of customer insights into operational improvements and adviser communication updates.
procedureSteps: Aggregate feedback from multiple channels into the central tracker.
Score themes using impact and effort to inform backlog prioritisation.
Communicate top themes and progress in newsletters or adviser calls.
edgeCases: Feedback volume spikes - segment by persona to identify root causes.
No immediate fix available - share interim guidance and review dates.
Adviser unaware their feedback was actioned - close the loop proactively.

miniCheck.prompt: Why is impact versus effort scoring used on feedback themes?

options.label: To prioritise improvements that deliver the greatest value for the effort required
options.feedback: Correct - impact and effort scoring guides prioritisation (page 46).

options.label: To slow down decision making
options.feedback: Scoring accelerates prioritisation.

options.label: To focus only on marketing feedback
options.feedback: Scoring applies to all themes, not just marketing.

options.label: To decide which advisers to remove from the platform
options.feedback: Adviser removal is unrelated to scoring.

miniCheck.prompt: How should outcomes be shared with advisers?

options.label: Highlight top changes in newsletters or release notes
options.feedback: Correct - sharing outcomes shows responsiveness (page 47).

options.label: Contact advisers who raised the feedback directly when it is resolved
options.feedback: Correct - direct follow up builds loyalty (page 47).

options.label: Hide all updates to avoid raising expectations
options.feedback: Transparency is important.

options.label: Only share updates internally
options.feedback: Advisers should hear outcomes too.

miniCheck.prompt: True or false: Impact and effort scoring helps teams focus on high value improvements.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

example.label: Feedback storytelling
example.scenario: A cluster of advisers requested clearer corporate action updates, and the product team delivered improvements.
example.application: Summarise the change in the newsletter, notify the advisers who raised it, and update the knowledge base script.

takeaways: Impact and effort scoring helps teams focus on high value improvements.
Closing the loop converts feedback into stronger relationships.
Voice of customer insights should inform product, training, and communication plans.
nextActions: Update this week voice of customer summary for leadership.
Ensure release notes include a section on adviser requested changes.

quizzes.title: Edge Platform Architecture Foundations Knowledge Check
quizzes.description: Contrast the legacy FirstWrap and FirstChoice constraints with Edge streaming services, capacity uplift, and the separation timeline.

items.prompt: Which legacy constraint drove the Edge rebuild with FNZ?

options.label: Monolithic databases that forced 4-6 hour data refresh cycles
options.feedback: Correct - the overnight batch model was a major adviser pain point (page 1).

options.label: Low adviser brand awareness outside Australia
options.feedback: Brand perception is important but not the architectural driver.

options.label: Contact centre headcount caps during peak season
options.feedback: Staffing pressures are noted elsewhere but not as the rebuild trigger.

options.label: Regulators banning integrations to adviser CRMs
options.feedback: Edge actually expands API connectivity, it was not banned.

items.prompt: How can an agent best describe Edge concurrency improvements?

options.label: Explain the move to a cloud distributed architecture scaling beyond 50,000 sessions
options.feedback: Correct - the training guide highlights the new capacity target (page 2).

options.label: State that batch windows now run twice per day
options.feedback: Batch windows were removed, so this would be incorrect.

options.label: Mention the 23 direct API connections that remove duplicate data entry
options.feedback: Correct - the API footprint is a major improvement (page 2).

options.label: Promise a permanent five minute nightly outage window
options.feedback: No nightly outage window is documented in the guide.

items.prompt: True or false: Edge removes batch refresh and manual reporting bottlenecks advisers remember.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

quizzes.title: Onboarding Clients on CFS Edge Knowledge Check
quizzes.description: Guide advisers through digital identity capture, trust documentation, and condition of release governance in the Edge onboarding workspace.

items.prompt: Which condition of release status must display before pension onboarding can proceed?

options.label: Met
options.feedback: Correct - Edge prevents pension activation until condition of release shows Met (page 23).

options.label: Pending adviser signature
options.feedback: Pending indicates further validation is needed.

options.label: Deemed satisfied
options.feedback: This status is not part of the Edge gating rules.

options.label: Waived
options.feedback: Conditions of release cannot be waived in the workflow.

items.prompt: What is the correct response when an SMSF ABN shows inactive?

options.label: Ask the trustee to refresh ASIC registration before Edge can continue
options.feedback: Correct - the platform enforces live ASIC status as a blocker (page 5).

options.label: Continue onboarding while a manual override is raised
options.feedback: Overrides are not permitted for compliance gates.

options.label: Switch the account to an individual profile temporarily
options.feedback: Switching entity type introduces compliance issues.

options.label: Escalate directly to the payments queue
options.feedback: Payments cannot resolve an ASIC registration issue.

items.prompt: True or false: Always lock down entity and authority data before diving into forms.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

quizzes.title: Asset Transfers and IDPS In-Specie Strategy Knowledge Check
quizzes.description: Differentiate internal, external, and IDPS in-specie transfers, quoting accurate settlement windows, tax considerations, and history reconstruction steps.

items.prompt: What settlement window should be quoted for a Category A internal transfer?

options.label: 1-2 business days with no tax implication
options.feedback: Correct - internal transfers move quickly without triggering tax (page 7).

options.label: 5-10 business days with potential capital gains tax
options.feedback: This timing applies to IDPS in-specie transfers, not internal movements.

options.label: Up to four weeks while performance history rebuilds
options.feedback: History reconstruction is separate from the settlement window.

options.label: Next day provided a supervisor approves the request
options.feedback: Supervisor approval is not documented as a requirement.

items.prompt: Which talking points reassure advisers about IDPS in-specie moves?

options.label: Explain that holdings move without sell downs so cost base records stay intact
options.feedback: Correct - preserving cost base history is a key benefit (page 9).

options.label: Mention that settlement now lands inside 5-10 business days
options.feedback: Correct - the June 2025 uplift delivers the faster window (page 9).

options.label: Promise daily tax reporting while the transfer is open
options.feedback: The guide does not promise daily tax reporting updates.

options.label: State that all corporate actions pause until settlement completes
options.feedback: Corporate actions continue unless a custodian specifies otherwise.

items.prompt: True or false: Always identify the transfer category before quoting timelines or tax outcomes.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

quizzes.title: Transacting and Managing Accounts Knowledge Check
quizzes.description: Support trade placement, cash sweeps, and corporate action coordination using the upgraded trading workspace.

items.prompt: Which workspace enhancement helps advisers validate managed account trades?

options.label: Tax lot visibility alongside unrealised gains
options.feedback: Correct - the trading workspace surfaces tax lots and gains (page 12).

options.label: A forced five minute delay before every order
options.feedback: No mandatory delay is mentioned in the guide.

options.label: Removal of compliance prompts during order entry
options.feedback: Compliance prompts remain to protect investors.

options.label: Auto cancellation of all trades after market close
options.feedback: Trades are not auto cancelled after close by default.

items.prompt: How should agents coach advisers on settlement awareness?

options.label: Confirm the settlement cut off while reviewing the trade ticket
options.feedback: Correct - reinforcing cut offs prevents missed settlements (page 13).

options.label: Suggest checking the cash ladder and sweep rules before submitting
options.feedback: Correct - cash sweeps ensure funds are ready for settlement (page 13).

options.label: Advise waiting for the nightly email summary before calling clients
options.feedback: Nightly summaries should not replace proactive communication.

options.label: Tell advisers to disable compliance prompts for faster entry
options.feedback: Compliance prompts should remain enabled.

items.prompt: True or false: Always verify cash availability and sweep behaviour before trade entry.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

quizzes.title: Reporting and Analytics Deep Dive Knowledge Check
quizzes.description: Explore interactive reporting, custom date ranges, and look-through analytics so advisers can self serve complex performance questions.

items.prompt: Which feature differentiates Edge reporting from the legacy platforms?

options.label: Custom date range selection with instant visual updates
options.feedback: Correct - custom ranges render instantly on Edge (page 18).

options.label: Reports restricted to quarter end periods
options.feedback: Edge removed the quarter end restriction.

options.label: Mandatory overnight batches to generate PDF outputs
options.feedback: Reports now generate on demand.

options.label: Removal of look-through analytics
options.feedback: Look-through analytics are a headline addition.

items.prompt: How should agents respond to advisers requesting visibility beyond their permission set?

options.label: Confirm whether a family group permission exists before sharing data
options.feedback: Correct - visibility is permission based (page 19).

options.label: Offer to email raw CSV exports regardless of permissions
options.feedback: Raw exports should never bypass permissions.

options.label: Suggest using the adviser branded PDF export instead
options.feedback: Correct - branded PDFs respect permissions and are client safe (page 19).

options.label: Encourage sharing screenshots from internal admin consoles
options.feedback: Screenshots risk leaking restricted information.

items.prompt: True or false: Custom ranges and look-through dashboards reduce manual spreadsheet work.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

quizzes.title: Security, Access, and Authentication Knowledge Check
quizzes.description: Cover multi-factor authentication, session management, and adviser access governance in the redesigned login experience.

items.prompt: Why did Edge remove the login countdown timer?

options.label: To reduce anxiety and improve accessibility for users
options.feedback: Correct - the redesign focused on calmer login experiences (page 22).

options.label: Because MFA codes no longer expire
options.feedback: MFA codes still expire; the timer change is unrelated.

options.label: Due to ASIC enforcing a maximum session length
options.feedback: ASIC limits are not cited as the reason.

options.label: To allow guest logins without authentication
options.feedback: Guest logins are not part of the program.

items.prompt: Which steps belong in the emergency access escalation path?

options.label: Verify client impact and document the service ticket number
options.feedback: Correct - documentation is mandatory (page 21).

options.label: Bypass security review to restore access instantly
options.feedback: Bypasses are not permitted.

options.label: Notify the security operations mailbox and quote the Severity matrix
options.feedback: Correct - severity alignment keeps the incident traceable (page 21).

options.label: Share passwords over the phone if the adviser insists
options.feedback: Passwords must never be shared verbally.

items.prompt: True or false: Security resets require identity verification before any change is made.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

quizzes.title: Superannuation and Pension Functionality Knowledge Check
quizzes.description: Manage pension schedules, contribution caps, and condition of release safeguards for retirement clients.

items.prompt: Which factor must be verified before altering pension payments?

options.label: Condition of release status is Met
options.feedback: Correct - payment changes are blocked until COR is Met (page 23).

options.label: The account has more than $50,000 cash
options.feedback: Cash balance alone is not a blocker.

options.label: The adviser has a marketing campaign running
options.feedback: Campaigns do not affect pension adjustments.

options.label: ATO exempted the client from annual reporting
options.feedback: Exemptions are not mentioned.

items.prompt: What should advisers communicate when increasing pension payment frequency?

options.label: Review year to date vs minimum drawdown before confirming
options.feedback: Correct - year to date tracking prevents breaches (page 24).

options.label: Confirm new bank details and cut off dates with the client
options.feedback: Correct - banking details and timing must be reconfirmed (page 24).

options.label: Advise that condition of release resets automatically
options.feedback: Condition of release does not reset automatically.

options.label: Skip documentation if the adviser knows the client well
options.feedback: Documentation is always required.

items.prompt: True or false: Condition of release is the gating factor for any pension adjustment.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

quizzes.title: Insurance Product Enhancements Knowledge Check
quizzes.description: Cover insurance transfer upgrades, advice fee consent changes, and occupation based underwriting updates.

items.prompt: What benefit does the multi document consent uplift deliver?

options.label: Allows several advice documents in one consolidated consent request
options.feedback: Correct - July 2025 introduced multi document consent (page 27).

options.label: Removes the need for client signatures entirely
options.feedback: Signatures remain mandatory.

options.label: Automatically approves all advice fees up to $10,000
options.feedback: Fee approvals are still assessed case by case.

options.label: Eliminates cooling off periods on replacement cover
options.feedback: Cooling off periods still apply.

items.prompt: Which steps help manage an insurance occupation change review?

options.label: Collect the new occupation details and remuneration band
options.feedback: Correct - underwriters require current occupation data (page 28).

options.label: Submit the request without supporting documents to save time
options.feedback: Supporting documents are required for underwriting.

options.label: Explain typical insurer turnaround so the adviser can set client expectations
options.feedback: Correct - expectation setting is a key coaching point (page 28).

options.label: Promise that premiums will not change
options.feedback: Premium outcomes cannot be guaranteed.

items.prompt: True or false: Consent consolidation simplifies adviser workflows but still needs full disclosure.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

quizzes.title: Common Adviser and Client Queries Knowledge Check
quizzes.description: Use the curated scripts to answer high frequency questions on digital access, reporting, transfers, and escalation etiquette.

items.prompt: What is the first action when using a scripted response?

options.label: Confirm the caller context and align the script before reading
options.feedback: Correct - alignment comes before reading verbatim (page 29).

options.label: Read the script word for word without pause
options.feedback: Scripts should be personalised.

options.label: Send the script via email instead of speaking
options.feedback: Live conversations need spoken responses.

options.label: Transfer the call to a supervisor
options.feedback: Supervisors are only needed for escalations.

items.prompt: How can agents keep scripted answers empathetic?

options.label: Paraphrase the core issue before giving the solution
options.feedback: Correct - paraphrasing shows active listening (page 29).

options.label: Use the caller name once near the end
options.feedback: Names should be used naturally throughout.

options.label: Highlight what changed in Edge that resolves the issue
options.feedback: Correct - linking improvements builds credibility (page 29).

options.label: Avoid offering follow up documentation
options.feedback: Follow up documentation reinforces understanding.

items.prompt: True or false: Scripts are a starting point that must be personalised to the caller.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

quizzes.title: Agent Response to Complaints and Escalations Knowledge Check
quizzes.description: Follow the severity matrix, response scripts, and recovery commitments when handling complaints or escalations.

items.prompt: What differentiates a Severity 1 incident?

options.label: Platform wide outage or breach needing immediate CTO and Service Desk engagement
options.feedback: Correct - Severity 1 covers critical outages or breaches (page 34).

options.label: Any incident where the client sounds upset
options.feedback: Emotional tone alone does not define severity.

options.label: Requests to change login preferences
options.feedback: Login changes are routine service requests.

options.label: Adviser asking about delayed paperwork
options.feedback: Delays alone may be Severity 2 or 3 depending on impact.

items.prompt: Which steps belong in the recovery outline you provide to callers?

options.label: Name the action owner and timeframe for the next update
options.feedback: Correct - transparency builds trust (page 33).

options.label: Avoid summarising the issue to save time
options.feedback: Summaries confirm shared understanding.

options.label: Explain any compensating controls or temporary workarounds
options.feedback: Correct - workarounds reduce impact (page 33).

options.label: Promise resolution within 24 hours regardless of scope
options.feedback: Do not promise unrealistic resolution times.

items.prompt: True or false: Severity levels dictate which stakeholders and channels become involved.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

quizzes.title: Self-Service Promotion Strategy Knowledge Check
quizzes.description: Promote Edge digital tools, highlight upcoming features, and coach advisers on adopting self-service workflows.

items.prompt: Which tactic reinforces adoption of the What Changed banner?

options.label: Encourage advisers to pin the banner and review updates weekly
options.feedback: Correct - weekly review keeps teams current (page 35).

options.label: Advise ignoring the banner until quarterly reviews
options.feedback: Quarterly cadence is too slow for rapid releases.

options.label: Send physical mailers summarising updates
options.feedback: Mailers are not highlighted in the guide.

options.label: Disable the banner if advisers find it distracting
options.feedback: Disabling removes key update visibility.

items.prompt: How can agents track digital adoption momentum?

options.label: Monitor telemetry dashboards showing form submission volumes
options.feedback: Correct - telemetry helps quantify adoption (page 35).

options.label: Request qualitative feedback during wrap up calls
options.feedback: Correct - feedback pairs with telemetry for context (page 35).

options.label: Assume adoption if there are no complaints
options.feedback: Silence does not confirm adoption.

options.label: Rely solely on marketing email open rates
options.feedback: Email opens are not sufficient evidence.

items.prompt: True or false: Self-service promotion must be tailored to adviser workflows and benefits.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

quizzes.title: Team Contacts and Escalation Matrix Knowledge Check
quizzes.description: Navigate the escalation matrix, identify primary contacts, and coordinate handovers across operations, product, and compliance teams.

items.prompt: When should the real time bridge be activated?

options.label: For Severity 1 incidents that require live coordination
options.feedback: Correct - the bridge is reserved for Severity 1 (page 36).

options.label: For routine document follow ups
options.feedback: Routine follow ups belong in standard queues.

options.label: Whenever an adviser requests a callback
options.feedback: Callbacks alone do not justify the bridge.

options.label: For marketing announcements
options.feedback: Marketing updates use regular channels.

items.prompt: Which handover details are essential when logging an escalation?

options.label: Summary of the issue, severity, and desired outcome
options.feedback: Correct - context and desired outcome set receiving teams up (page 37).

options.label: Copy of adviser email threads
options.feedback: Correct - attaching evidence avoids duplicate discovery (page 37).

options.label: Personal opinions about the adviser
options.feedback: Personal opinions are inappropriate for handovers.

options.label: Assumptions about root cause without data
options.feedback: Stick to facts and observations.

items.prompt: True or false: Using the matrix correctly keeps critical incidents on track.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

quizzes.title: Handling Difficult Calls and De-Escalation Knowledge Check
quizzes.description: Apply the four step de-escalation framework to acknowledge emotion, reframe issues, and secure agreement on next steps.

items.prompt: What is the first step in the de-escalation framework?

options.label: Acknowledge the emotion and show you heard their concern
options.feedback: Correct - acknowledgement comes before solutioning (page 38).

options.label: Offer compensation immediately
options.feedback: Compensation decisions come later if needed.

options.label: Transfer the call to a peer
options.feedback: Transfers are a last resort.

options.label: Start reciting policy clauses
options.feedback: Policy citations happen after empathy and reframing.

items.prompt: Which behaviours help secure agreement at the end of the call?

options.label: Summarise the agreed action and confirm the owner
options.feedback: Correct - clarity avoids missed expectations (page 40).

options.label: Check for adviser agreement before closing
options.feedback: Correct - shared agreement prevents rework (page 40).

options.label: Avoid restating timeframes to keep the call short
options.feedback: Timeframes must be restated.

options.label: Skip wrap up emails when the call was long
options.feedback: Wrap up emails remain important.

items.prompt: True or false: Acknowledgement and reframing are the foundation for productive calls.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

quizzes.title: Quality Assurance and Performance Monitoring Knowledge Check
quizzes.description: Understand the QA rubric, scorecard cadence, and how to coach peers using call and case insights.

items.prompt: Which dimension is highlighted in the QA rubric?

options.label: Accuracy and compliance of information shared
options.feedback: Correct - accuracy is a core rubric pillar (page 41).

options.label: Agent social media follower count
options.feedback: Social metrics are not part of QA.

options.label: Number of vacation days taken
options.feedback: Time off is unrelated to QA scoring.

options.label: Volume of small talk on calls
options.feedback: Small talk is not scored.

items.prompt: How should supervisors use QA data during coaching?

options.label: Lead with positive observations before discussing gaps
options.feedback: Correct - balanced feedback improves uptake (page 41).

options.label: Set clear action items with due dates and follow ups
options.feedback: Correct - action orientation closes gaps (page 41).

options.label: Share QA results only annually
options.feedback: Feedback should be timely.

options.label: Avoid written coaching notes to save time
options.feedback: Notes ensure accountability.

items.prompt: True or false: QA highlights both compliance and customer experience behaviours.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

quizzes.title: Regulatory and Compliance Landscape Knowledge Check
quizzes.description: Stay current on AML, advice fee consent, privacy obligations, and regulatory reporting tied to Edge operations.

items.prompt: Which item must be retained when processing advice fee consent?

options.label: Signed consent documents covering the relevant advice period
options.feedback: Correct - signed documents are mandatory (page 44).

options.label: A verbal confirmation without recording
options.feedback: Verbal confirmation alone is insufficient.

options.label: An agent personal diary entry
options.feedback: Personal notes do not satisfy compliance.

options.label: Screenshots of marketing brochures
options.feedback: Brochures are not consent evidence.

items.prompt: What triggers an AML escalation according to the guide?

options.label: Suspicious transaction patterns that do not align to known behaviour
options.feedback: Correct - unusual transactions must be escalated (page 44).

options.label: Client refusing to provide identification documents
options.feedback: Correct - refusal to provide ID triggers escalation (page 44).

options.label: Adviser requesting a marketing brochure
options.feedback: Marketing requests are not AML triggers.

options.label: Receiving positive feedback from a client
options.feedback: Positive feedback is unrelated to AML.

items.prompt: True or false: Compliance conversations must be factual and supported with documented evidence.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

quizzes.title: Ongoing Training and Enablement Calendar Knowledge Check
quizzes.description: Coordinate monthly enablement themes, align squads with delivery dates, and keep advisers informed about upcoming sessions.

items.prompt: How should agents promote upcoming enablement sessions?

options.label: Connect the session theme to specific adviser outcomes
options.feedback: Correct - framing value drives attendance (page 45).

options.label: Send calendar invites without context
options.feedback: Context is necessary to secure interest.

options.label: Share internal planning documents
options.feedback: Internal plans should stay internal.

options.label: Promise CE credits without confirmation
options.feedback: Only promise credits once confirmed.

items.prompt: Which follow ups reinforce training value?

options.label: Send recordings and key resources after the session
options.feedback: Correct - resources extend impact (page 45).

options.label: Collect feedback and share it with content owners
options.feedback: Correct - feedback loops improve future sessions (page 45).

options.label: Ignore attendance data
options.feedback: Attendance trends should be tracked.

options.label: Remove sessions once they pass to avoid clutter
options.feedback: Past sessions should remain accessible via recordings.

items.prompt: True or false: Tie training invitations to tangible adviser benefits or efficiencies.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

quizzes.title: Feedback Loop and Continuous Improvement Knowledge Check
quizzes.description: Capture, categorise, and action adviser feedback through sprint reviews, content updates, and release notes.

items.prompt: Which detail must every feedback submission include?

options.label: Persona or segment impacted along with the described issue
options.feedback: Correct - persona tagging aids prioritisation (page 46).

options.label: Agent personal opinion about the feature
options.feedback: Personal opinions are optional at best.

options.label: Internal team hierarchy charts
options.feedback: Hierarchy charts are unrelated.

options.label: A marketing tagline suggestion
options.feedback: Taglines are not required.

items.prompt: How do agents close the loop once feedback ships?

options.label: Notify the adviser that raised the feedback with release details
options.feedback: Correct - closing the loop builds trust (page 47).

options.label: Update knowledge base articles or scripts if behaviour changed
options.feedback: Correct - collateral must match new behaviour (page 47).

options.label: Delete the original feedback record
options.feedback: Records should be kept for history.

options.label: Avoid sharing release notes to limit expectations
options.feedback: Release notes help set expectations.

items.prompt: True or false: Structured tagging ensures feedback reaches the right squads quickly.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

quizzes.title: Additional Scenarios and Edge Cases Knowledge Check
quizzes.description: Prepare for rare but high impact scenarios spanning outage bridges, complex transfers, and specialised client needs.

items.prompt: What should agents reference first when a rare scenario surfaces?

options.label: The scenario index to identify owners and severity
options.feedback: Correct - the index is the starting point (page 48).

options.label: Personal memory of previous incidents
options.feedback: Personal memory may be incomplete.

options.label: Marketing materials
options.feedback: Marketing content does not guide scenarios.

options.label: External social media posts
options.feedback: Social posts are not official guidance.

items.prompt: Which behaviours help teams learn from edge cases?

options.label: Document lessons learned and feed them into playbook updates
options.feedback: Correct - documentation improves future responses (page 48).

options.label: Share scenario recaps during weekly standups
options.feedback: Correct - sharing keeps teams ready (page 48).

options.label: Avoid talking about challenging cases to reduce anxiety
options.feedback: Avoidance reduces readiness.

options.label: Rely on memory instead of playbooks
options.feedback: Playbooks exist to reduce risk.

items.prompt: True or false: Scenario readiness starts with knowing where to find owners and playbooks.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

quizzes.title: Communication Best Practices Knowledge Check
quizzes.description: Deliver clear, empathetic, and action oriented communications across email, phone, and bridge updates.

items.prompt: What does the ACE structure stand for?

options.label: Acknowledge, Clarify, Execute
options.feedback: Correct - ACE underpins the communication model (page 49).

options.label: Ask, Confirm, Escalate
options.feedback: Ask, Confirm, Escalate is not the documented model.

options.label: Assess, Coach, Evaluate
options.feedback: Assess, Coach, Evaluate relates to training.

options.label: Align, Challenge, Exit
options.feedback: Align, Challenge, Exit is not referenced.

items.prompt: Which behaviours keep adviser emails effective?

options.label: Lead with the acknowledgement before outlining updates
options.feedback: Correct - acknowledgement shows empathy (page 49).

options.label: Include clear next actions and owners
options.feedback: Correct - clarity on next steps builds trust (page 49).

options.label: Use dense paragraphs without headings
options.feedback: Dense paragraphs reduce clarity.

options.label: Avoid stating timelines to stay flexible
options.feedback: Timelines are essential to manage expectations.

items.prompt: True or false: ACE keeps communications focused and empathetic.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

quizzes.title: Final Checklists and Reference Tools Knowledge Check
quizzes.description: Leverage final checklists, cheat sheets, and decision trees to maintain quality and speed across Edge interactions.

items.prompt: Why are the final checklists critical for quality assurance?

options.label: They ensure mandatory documentation is not missed before closing a case
options.feedback: Correct - checklists protect completeness (page 50).

options.label: They replace the need for training
options.feedback: Checklists complement training but do not replace it.

options.label: They allow bypassing compliance reviews
options.feedback: Compliance reviews remain mandatory.

options.label: They generate marketing content automatically
options.feedback: Marketing content is unrelated.

items.prompt: How should decision trees be used during live calls?

options.label: Keep them visible and step through the decision flow with the caller
options.feedback: Correct - walking through the tree boosts accuracy (page 50).

options.label: Skip them to save time when the call is simple
options.feedback: Skipping risks missing important steps.

options.label: Note any unexpected branches for future updates
options.feedback: Correct - feedback keeps decision trees current (page 50).

options.label: Share screenshots externally without context
options.feedback: Screenshots should not be shared externally.

items.prompt: True or false: Checklists, decision trees, and cheat sheets keep quality consistent.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

quizzes.title: Streaming Telemetry and Platform Monitoring Knowledge Check
quizzes.description: Explain how Edge streaming telemetry powers live dashboards, health monitoring, and proactive incident communication.

items.prompt: What did streaming telemetry replace from the legacy platform?

options.label: Overnight batch health checks that delayed incident detection
options.feedback: Correct - batch based monitoring was replaced by streaming (page 2).

options.label: Proactive client communication
options.feedback: Communication remains the agent responsibility.

options.label: API integrations with adviser CRMs
options.feedback: APIs were expanded, not removed.

options.label: Corporate action processing
options.feedback: Corporate actions are unrelated to telemetry.

items.prompt: How should telemetry be used during incident updates?

options.label: Reference the dashboard trend to validate adviser reports
options.feedback: Correct - telemetry confirms impact (page 2).

options.label: Share raw internal dashboard screenshots externally
options.feedback: Internal dashboards should not be shared.

options.label: Record the telemetry reference in the case notes
options.feedback: Correct - documentation supports incident reviews (page 2).

options.label: Ignore telemetry when a single adviser calls
options.feedback: Telemetry should still be checked.

items.prompt: True or false: Streaming telemetry enables faster incident validation and response.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

quizzes.title: API Integration Playbook Knowledge Check
quizzes.description: Support advisers using Edge APIs to connect CRMs, planning tools, and data warehouses.

items.prompt: Which adviser platforms have direct Edge API connections?

options.label: Iress and AdviserLogic
options.feedback: Correct - both are named API partners (page 2).

options.label: Netwealth API gateway
options.feedback: Correct - Netwealth connectivity is listed (page 2).

options.label: Random social media tools
options.feedback: Social media tools are not referenced.

options.label: Legacy FirstWrap batch feeds only
options.feedback: Batch feeds were replaced by live APIs.

items.prompt: What should be collected before escalating an API issue?

options.label: Error payloads, timestamps, and the endpoint being called
options.feedback: Correct - diagnostics enable faster resolution (page 2).

options.label: A screenshot of the adviser desktop wallpaper
options.feedback: Wallpapers are irrelevant.

options.label: The agent star rating
options.feedback: Star ratings are not used.

options.label: Marketing preferences of the adviser
options.feedback: Marketing preferences are unrelated.

items.prompt: True or false: API support begins with verifying partner and credential readiness.

options.label: True
options.feedback: Correct - this statement is documented in the training guide.

options.label: False
options.feedback: The guide confirms this statement, so treat it as true.

quizzes.title: Digital Identity Verification Essentials Knowledge Check
quizzes.description: Master the digital identity capture steps, document requirements, and fallback processes for Edge onboarding.

items.prompt: Which documents must be certified for trust onboarding?

options.label: Trust deed and trustee identification documents
options.feedback: Correct - both must be certified (page 4).

options.label: Marketing brochures
options.feedback: Brochures are optional, not mandatory.

options.label: Call recordings
options.feedback: Recordings are not part of identity capture.

options.label: Investment questionnaires
options.feedback: Questionnaires support suitability, not identity.

items.prompt: How should failed electronic verification be handled?

options.label: Trigger manual review and advise on expected turnaround
options.feedback: Correct - manual review picks up failed checks (page 5).

options.label: Proceed anyway to avoid delays
